item.title: Measurement of Silica Particles by Transmission Electron Microscope - Updated
item.author: Kole, Frank
item.summary: Particles of known sizes have been essential for calibrating the sensitivity of semiconductor wafer inspection systems. As more advanced inspection systems harness ultraviolet (UV) and deep ultraviolet (DUV) illumination to resolve smaller structures, there is a growing industry need for a new generation of particle standards that resist damage at these shorter wavelengths. This paper summarizes the techniques and results for the traceable measurement of a large array of silica particle sizes, using established methods in transmission electron microscopy (TEM), along with semi-automated digital image processing. We report the mean maximum diameters and expanded uncertainties for each of 14 particle sizes, ranging from nominal diameters of 32 nm to 1500 nm. ​

item.title: Local Color Filter
item.author: Huang, Jenny
item.summary: The goal is to improve DOI sensitivity with the presence of local color variation. Often times DOIs were detuned due to overwhelming presence of color variation. Color variation could have strong difference yet it does not come from abnormality of the substrate. With Local Color Filter, we can greatly reduce the nuisance rate during ​ post processing when color variation is the nuisance source. ​ ​

item.title: Optical Distortion Correction in WaferSight 3
item.author: Dudin, Yaroslav
item.summary: WaferSight3 (WS3) is a bare wafer metrology system capable of measuring wafer thickness, shape, nanotopography, and derived metrics. At the core of the measurement system is a dual-sided Fizeau interferometer with clear aperture sufficient to capture a full 450 mm diameter silicon wafer. Geometric distortions of the optical system limit the measurement accuracy. Here we propose and demonstrate an optical distortion calibration method as well as a new wafer thickness calculation procedure. ​​​

item.title: Protection of EUV Lithography Masks: Showerhead Flow Mitigation of Nanoscale Particulate Contamination
item.author: Chilese, Frank
item.summary: We analyze a method to protect the reticle (mask) in an EUV mask inspection tool that uses a showerhead plenum to provide a continuous flow of clean gas over the surface of a reticle. The reticle is suspended in an inverted fashion (face down) within a stage/holder that moves back and forth over the showerhead plenum as the reticle is inspected. It is essential that no particles of 10-nm diameter or larger be deposited on the reticle during inspection. Particles can originate from multiple sources in the system, and mask protection from each source is explicitly analyzed. The showerhead plate has an internal plenum with a solid conical wall isolating the aperture. The upper and lower surfaces of the plate are thin flat sheets of porous-metal material. These porous sheets form the top and bottom showerheads that supply the region between the showerhead plate and the reticle and the region between the conical aperture and the Optics Zone box with continuous flows of clean gas. The model studies show that the top showerhead provides robust reticle protection from particles of 10-nm diameter or larger originating from the Reticle Zone and from plenum surfaces contaminated by exposure to the Reticle Zone. The bottom showerhead efficiently protects the reticle from nanoscale particles originating from the Optics Zone. With similar mass flow rates from the two showerheads, this system provides efficient protection even when a significant overpressure exists between the Optics Zone and the Reticle Zone. Performance is insensitive to the fraction of incident particles that sticks to walls, the accommodation coefficient, the aperture geometry, and the gas pressure. The showerheads also protect the aperture (and therefore the Optics Zone) during loading and unloading. Commercially available porous-metal media have properties suitable for these showerheads at the required flow rates. ​

item.title: Multi-View Tomography for Review and Inspection Microscopes
item.author: Sezginer, Apo
item.summary: We propose a computational method that is suitable for a review microscope with a laser source. A high-resolution image is computed from multiple optical images of the same object illuminated from different directions. The goal is to maximize the image resolution and modulation beyond what can be achieved with a single illumination pattern. ​

item.title: Dynamic Care Area Discovery
item.author: Ramachandran, Vijay
item.summary:
​Currently Care Areas are treated as static entities that are defined at recipe setup time. Improvements in coordinate accuracy have shown that shrinking care areas to very small sizes can improve the sensitivity of the inspection by spatially seperating the noise in areas surrounding the defect. But these "micro" care areas are still static and created in the setup step.

Recently there has also been a development of the "Discovery" use case, where a design enabled inspection is able to detect systematic pattern failures on the wafer. Discovery use case has been an important and successful use case in the NanoPoint family of tools.

This paper is presents an idea for PWQ involved with finding larger defects of pattern failures in higher modulation (where they are easier to detect) and generating dynamic care areas that help detection of the same defect types in lower modulation where we may otherwise not have the sensitivity to detect them.

item.title: Advanced Packaging and Materials for High Performance Imaging Sensors
item.author: Lehman, Kurt
item.summary: An overview of ​current successes and future challenges in meeting the needs of high-performance image acquisition in wafer inspection tools, including integration, materials, electrical, and thermal considerations.

item.title: The Shot-Noise Challenge of EUV Lithography
item.author: Smith, Mark D.
item.summary: The semiconductor industry has maintained Moore’s law by either increasing the numerical aperture (NA) or reducing the wavelength ( l ). The next generation lithography will reduce the wavelength 14 fold, from 193 nm (ArF) to 13.5 nm (EUV). The dramatic reduction in wavelength combined with a reduction in NA improves both resolution and depth of focus. However, because photon energy increases 14 fold, the number of photons decreases by the same factor for an equivalent exposure dose. Therefore, photon shot noise will be a much larger problem for EUV. Keeping the LER at an acceptable level requires a high exposure dose. Currently EUV light sources have limited power. High exposure doses require scanning slowly, which reduces throughput and increases the cost of ownership. Alternatively, new, high-powered EUV sources need to be developed. The dose-LER trade-off is central to the cost of ownership of EUVL. We explore the limits of the trade-off from two angles. First, we use a detailed model of the photoresist process and optimize its parameters. We show that LER has a lower bound due to photon shot-noise. Secondly, we estimate the shot-noise limit independent of resist properties. ​

item.title: Optical system alignment based on the Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)
item.author: Jain, Prateek

item.title: Small Angle X-ray Scattering for Semiconductor Metrology
item.author: Bakeman, Michael
item.summary:
​
The increasing complexity of semiconductor structures such as 3 dimensional FinFETs requires the development of metrology technologies capable of characterization with subnanometer precision. The small feature sizes of these structures is increasingly challenging for optical technologies such as spectroscopic ellipsometry due to the large wavelengths of the optical beam compared to the feature sizes of the structures. Critical Dimension Small Angle X-ray Scattering (CD-SAXS) is a technology which may have the ability to measure CD, pitch, line edge roughness, and cross sectional profile of both logic and memory structures [1]. The technique is based upon the transmission and scattering of a high energy x-ray beam through a patterned semiconductor wafer. As the beam passes through a periodic structure the scattered intensity is measured on a detector and an image of the scattering pattern is produced. The wafer is then rotated to change the angle of incidence of the x-ray beam and another image is produced, resulting in an angle resolved data set.

item.title: Pushing Envelope of WaferSight for PWG Applications
item.author: Chen, Haiguang
item.summary:
​​​​​​​

WaferSight tools have been designed, implemented and used to perform high quality bare wafer geometry measurements. Now WaferSight engineering team is working hard to enhance the tool capacity and extend its performance limits for many important patterned wafer geometry applications and open the new frontier for WaferSight business.

In PWG, there are often severe phase unwrapping errors introduced by the film and pattern structure variations on patterned wafer surface. Several new algorithm features have been investigated in PWG engineering team to address the problems encountered and improve the system performance for many important PWG applications.

1. Small Patch Phase Unwrapping and Filtering

Since many important PWG applications, such as IPD and stress analysis, nano-topography, are based on the surface height slope, surface height curvature and, in general, local surface height variation, the small patch phase unwrapping and filtering schemes have been designed not only to avoid the problems from the current global phase unwrapping but also to achieve the improved performance. For slope and curvature calculation, the small patch methods generate exactly the same results as traditionally derived from the surface height map in the wafer interior region while produce much better data quality in the wafer edge region.

For the slipline and many other edge region defect detection and quantification, one dimensional phase unwrapping is developed to naturally match the sharp wafer edge roll off characteristics and avoid the signal distortion and feature loss from the global two dimensional unwrapping of high slope phase map in the wafer edge region.

2. Adaptive Phase Map Filtering and Surface Reconstruction

To obtain more robust wafer height surface reconstruction from WaferSight measurements, the new algorithms are designed to perform the effective phase map filtering to suppress the components from sharp transitional pattern structures, which have resulted in global phase unwrapping errors. The filtering is adaptively controlled by the estimated local phase gradient orientation angle, magnitude and coherence level. The filtered phase map can then be used in the global phase unwrapping algorithm to generate pseudo-bare wafer surface map with the high frequency pattern structures suppressed. Subsequently the local phase unwrapping scheme is used to produce the local surface height variation map from the un-processed phase map. The combination of the pseudo-bare wafer surface map with the local surface variation map will reconstruct the complete wafer surface height map, and thus provide the valuable wafer thickness and shape information.​

item.title: Optimization of Optical Under-Sampling Rate For Actinic Mask Inspection Systems
item.author: Wang, Li
item.summary: Actinic EUV mask inspection is widely recognized as a necessity to enable the adoption of EUV lithography as the high volume manufacturing solution for the nodes below 20nm half pitch. Due to the high cost and highly complex nature of the EUV inspection tool, system parameter optimization including optical sampling rate is of great importance to maximize throughput, which in turn lowers the cost per inspection (CPI). In this study, we analyzed the impacts of sampling rate choices to 7xx system throughput, signal and noises, and proposed configurations of interest. The methodology can be useful for other optical inspection system designs, such as DUV mask and wafer inspection systems. ​

item.title: Phase shift interferometry with sparse array detectors for the measurement of pattern wafers
item.author: Tang, Shouhong
item.summary: ​Currently, our product WaferSight has a great difficulty to measure the shape of a patterned wafer with large warp. The method presented in this paper may provide the solution. It has been shown in this paper that the sparse array detector improves the pixel MTF or increases the fringe modulation. Once it is integrated with WaferSight, the detector makes this product not only be able to measure surfaces with large departures but also preserve PSI inherent superior measurement quality.

item.title: CCD Degradation for DUV and VUV inspection systems and new Technologies for the Next Generation Rapid systems
item.author: Barkusky, Frank
item.summary:
Current metrology tools using light for detecting structures or defects need detectors to convert the photons into an electronic signal. This can be diodes for measuring intensities or beam positions, or CCDs for detecting the light that gets transmitted and/or reflected from the sample. Besides sensitivity, readout speed, noise and homogeneity, the lifetime of those elements plays an important role in tool uptime and therefore customer satisfaction.

In current RAPID tools, a so called TDI (time delayed integration) detector is used as main detector. This is basically a special CCD camera that works with a special readout mode. Here, the photon generated charge moves across the TDI with the same speed as the image, therefore accumulating the signal resulting in both a better SNR and continuous readout.

Same as a CCD, this detector consists of a special structured and layered surface to generate and transport the photon generated electrons. For low wavelengths, this becomes a problem: due to the high photon energy of 193nm or 13.5nm radiation, standard TDIs and photo detectors based on Si technology degrade during exposure. This means, the responsivity of the detector changes over time, resulting in lower tool performance up to a failure of the TDI in the field. This behavior, however, is known also for other wavelengths in this region. Figure 3, for example, shows the shift of degradation to shorter dosages for wavelengths between 193 nm and 135 nm. For 135 nm, significant drop of responsivity already occurs for a radiant dose of less than 100mJ/cm²!

The main driver for this behavior is the penetration depth of the radiation (Fig. 4). In the region of 193nm and below, most photons are absorbed within the first 10th of nanometers. Here, the interaction of photons with the boundary layer between Si and SiO2 leads to a loss of sensitivity, which will be explained in more detail.

In our presentation we will present several effects leading to degradation of a TDI detector. We will discuss the wavelength dependence of those effects, and how degradation might be avoided or reduced to increase the lifetime of these elements. Furthermore, it will be presented how those effects can be measured in the lab to predict sensor lifetime for current and further RAPID tools. A main part will focus on the test bench for lifetime tests on the new EUV detector.


​

item.title: Leveraging the time-evolution of iDO binner performance to detect the emergence of new defect types
item.author: Huet, Patrick
item.summary: We catalog the statistical fluctuations that directly affect the performance of an iDO binner into two fundamental types, namely, defect count fluctuations (Type-I) and defect properties fluctuations (Type-II). Type-II fluctuations are particularly important as they may be indicative of the detection of a new defect type that might require a user action in form of [1] a process control change, or [2] an inspector recipe change, or [3] the maintenance of a KLA-Tencor inspector. Specifically, some "markers", numerical quantities derived from the iDO performance matrix, have been identified and shown to be particularly sensitive to Type-I and Type-II fluctuations. When monitored in time, i.e., from wafer to wafer in a production environment, these markers provide a mean to flag the emergence of new defect types and to distinguish them from other excursions.​

item.title: TBI Using Any-Shape Care and Don't Care Areas
item.author: Balaji, Aravindh
item.summary:
​Target-based inspection(TBI), initially developed as an integral part of NanoPoint, is a special technique to do inspection at specific locations with care areas as tiny as 250x250 nm(MCA). The advantage of TBI is to place care areas accurately by associating them with unique patterns of interest(POI). As the number of transistors per node increase at the rate of Moore's law, the defects in turn become sub-pixel in nature. By inspecting specific locations using localized context, we can detect these defects which in normal inspection would have been buried deep in the noise floor. TBI was designed for logic devices and rectangular care areas (CA) have been used in traditional inspection and TBI. Recently, a need was raised from memory manufacturers to inspect irregular shapes. To meet that requirement, we extend the concept of TBI to inspect or suppress nuisance by defining MCAs in any shape. Parametric curves are utilized for the CA generation and the localized context is provided by the shape of the MCA rather than a pre-defined location. This would help inspect transition regions on memory devices using TBI.

Results show that the proposed technique offer significant improvements in defect detection in comparison with the current approach. On testing it on a customer wafer, this approach provided an increase of 45x in sensitivity with less than 4% increase in throughput time on a full wafer scan.

item.title: NanoPoint: Target Based Inspection
item.author: Shifrin, Eugene
item.summary:
​​​​​​​​New NanoPoint algorithm - Target Based inspection (TBI) is discussed.

The algorithm allows care areas positioning on the wafer with precision and accuracy up to ±2 pixels.

Algorithm, setup and run flow as well as some results are discussed.​​

item.title: Application based calibration of optical metrology systems as a step towards improved tool-to-tool matching
item.author: Flock, Klaus
item.summary:
​

Method of matching critical dimension and thin film measurements at high precision for optical metrology systems is presented. Such systems are employed to measure structural and material characteristics (e.g., material composition, dimensional characteristics of structures and films, etc.) associated with different semiconductor fabrication processes. Calibration of machine parameter values of a metrology system are refined based upon based on critical dimension measurement data and customer applications. The proposed and demonstrated calibration approach may be employed to enhance application and tool-to-tool matching among systems for measurement of critical dimensions (CD), film thickness, film composition, and overlay at the precision level of the machines.

item.title: Orders engineering for overlay accuracy analysis
item.author: Manassen, Amnon
item.summary: Accuracy error analysis in imaging overlay and methods for improvement​

item.title: PSF Reconstruction from Undersampled Image through Super Resolution Method
item.author: Liu, Helen (Heng)
item.summary: As alternative to expensive/complicated optics system design in N+2 Eagle program, we propose to use algorithm approach to provide high resolution image for system response (PSF) reconstruction in special cases. The benefits include detection sensitivity, calibration, sizing accuracy, nuisance filtering etc.

item.title: EtchRate Sensing Wafer
item.author: Jensen, Earl
item.summary: ​​​Feasibility study of wireless sensor wafer has been conducted. This sensor wafer is designed to temporally and spatially resolve Etch Rate Uniformity (ERU) across the wafer during plasma etch. It can also be used during deposition processes to monitor growth of film thickness.​

item.title: Measuring EUV Mask Blank Defect Location with IPRO5+
item.author: Buettner, Alexander
item.summary: We explore inspecting EUV mask blanks with 6XX, and then refining the coordinates of the detected defects using IPRO5+ which has a more precise reticle stage. Imaging EUV blank defects with IPRO5+ is challenging because the plate signal is dominated by the phase defects of the instrument. We describe two strategies to extract the mask blank signal. ​

item.title: Angle-Resolved, Small-Spot Spectroscopic Ellipsometer using a novel Multi-segment Detector
item.author: Flock, Klaus
item.summary: We present a novel concept for an angle-resolved Spectroscopic Ellipsometer (SE) with the following key features: (i) Large Collection NA, (ii) SE data from multiple angular segments (AOIs) are simultaneously imaged on a novel, segmented detector, and (iii) SE data are simultaneously dispersed across the available wavelengths (190-1000 nm). This new design concept is expected to provide up to 30% reduction in the Spot Size, a 3x speedup in data acquisition and a 3x reduction in wafer exposure for a typical 3-AOI SE system. The details of the optical design and the multi-segment detector architecture will be presented together with a discussion of critical technical challenges.

item.title: Swimmy: A New Dimension in Log File Analysis
item.author: Craig, Tom
item.summary: Swimmy is a tool that consolidates diverse system log data, providing a variety of graphical tools to aid in activities such as problem diagnosis and performance analysis. Extensive value is added by enhancing engineering and technical support productivity. Complex problems that are difficult to solve with traditional methods are simplified with the use of Swimmy.

item.title: Thinking outside the box, an Optical Engineer's take
item.author: Zhang, Shiyu
item.summary:
The author has about 20 year of lens design experience, he would like to give some examples on thinking outside the box optical design experience. One example is the WIN DF 9850 line illumination generator. ​

"I am extremely busy now, do not have time to finish a well written abstrast. Will do it during the holidays".

item.title: Wide Dynamic Range by Pockels Effect Based Intensity Modulator
item.author: Shur, Dmitry
item.summary:
Optical metrology of semiconductor wafers inherently requires a wide dynamic range of light intensities to enable measurements of targets with completely different reflectivities. This challenge is increased even more by a wide range of new materials being introduced in semiconductor processing to meet requirements of new technology nodes. Addressing different wafer reflectivities that usually range from <1% up to the reflectivity of silicon (~48% at 405 nm), and even higher reflectivity values for backend metal layers, is an enabler to emerging scatterometry overlay tools.

The electro-optic light intensity modulator (based on Pockels effect) operated in ensemble with multiple polarizing beam splitters and single mode fiber allows laser light attenuation ratios >1000. The Pockels effect based electro-optic modulator (EOM) is a voltage controlled one. Combining the high attenuation light modulator with a reference detector (sensing light intensity right before the objective) into a system, light maps can be created as reference detector signal versus EOM voltage.

item.title: HALT (HIGHLY ACCELERATE LIFE TEST) AS AN EFFECTIVE TOOL FOR INTERMITTENT FAILURES RCA (ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS)
item.author: Eisenbach, Shlomo
item.summary:
HALT as an early Reliability test is traditionally applied during development time on one of the first samples available. In this paper we present the value of applying HALT post release to have fast but controlled root cause analysis in case of intermittent failure and slow degradation of performance.

Using a HALT test on a known field drift issue enabled us to pinpoint the root cause of a sensitive system level reliability issue which combined a within spec light source beam pointing instability with the method used to couple the light source beam into the imaging system. This knowledge enabled suggesting minor modifications to the illumination system and the alignment methods to prevent the drift.​

item.title: Scatterometry Overlay accuracy in case of inter-target’s cell process variation
item.author: Marciano, Tal
item.summary: As the performance of microlithography processes continuously increases with new design rule node, the metrology needs to overcome new challenges and increasing the measurement accuracy. Chemical mechanical polishing (CMP) is extensively used in semiconductor industry during process. It may cause process variation resulting in slight height difference across the wafer. Such process variation might lead to important inaccuracy in overlay scatterometry measurement. This paper focus on identifying and correcting the overlay measurement algorithm in case of such height variation between the four cells (pad-to-pad variation) constituting the SCOL 3 technology. ​

item.title: Linear Wafer Transporter
item.author: Hanfling, Yoram
item.summary: In this paper the advantages of a linear wafer Transporter over the SCARA approach is discussed and the KT Transporter design chanlenges are explained ​

item.title: Scatterometry overlay incorporating phase shift interferometry
item.author: Bringoltz, Barak
item.summary: We introduce a new overlay measurement paradigm which involves 1st order diffraction and phase shift interferometry, and that enables enhanced accuracy, minimal sensitivity to process variations, and high signal sensitivity to overlay. ​

item.title: KT Pre-Aligner: a Design-to-Cost Success Story
item.author: Shapiro, Yoel
item.summary: The KT Pre-Aligner is a successful example of a design to cost project that ended up reaching better performance than the products it was competing against. Careful analysis of the wafer alignment process allowed breaking down the error budget and identifying sub-component requirements that could be loosened. The usage of lower grade hardware and optics is compensated for by more sophisticated signal and image processing algorithms. The final product achieves the same performance as its nearest competitors, and even better, at 65% of the cost. ​

item.title: Active Planar Focus
item.author: Cavan, Dan
item.summary: A method to planarize the autofocus response while maintaining real time autofocus during inspection.​

item.title: Nanometer stage position accuracy
item.author: Balan, Aviv
item.summary: Proposal for a new way of using stage feedback system to support the Semiconductor industry requirements of nanometer accuracy ​

item.title: Noise analysis and measurement in SCOL based metrology with normalized signals
item.author: Immer, Vincent
item.summary:
A set up was realized to measure noise improvement using optical signal normalization. Noise level of 1.5E-10 relative variance was obtained from a laser source with relative variance of 8E-7.

Optical normalization did not significantly improve the SNR of the CCD signal. Camera noise with a relative variance down to 7.3E-7 was measured.

The main source of noise is in the camera itself.

This experiment explains the reason a photodiode normalization done in SCOL does not provide a significant noise improvement compared to pupil normalization.​

item.title: Experimental apparatus for research and development of EUV light sources for 7xx mask inspectors
item.author: Tsigutkin, Konstantin
item.summary: ​​It has been demonstrated experimentally that the LPP source utilizing solid-xenon target yields brightness figure high enough to satisfy requirements of the mask inspection tools. The EUV emission volume is spherically symmetric and 100 microns in diameter. The source brightness reaches a value of 11.8 W/(mm2 str) , which is a highest brightness observed in Xe-based kHz-range EUV sources so far.

item.title: WIN NextGen Common Platform Architecture
item.author: Kaveh, Farro
item.summary: The emergence of 450mm wafer size provided an opportunity to rethink the architecture of the tool. Additionally, the ever increasing demand on the next generation BBP and LS tools for better resolution and defect detection capability requires significant improvements not only in the optics, image acquisition, and associated algorithm and sw, but the infrastructure of the tool, from the frame, power distribution, air flow management, thermal control, and others. Further, in order to optimize the CoGS, the CoS, outsourcing of major assemblies, manufacturing flexibility, FRU stocking levels, maximum commonality between the various tools is highly desirable. A common platform architecture was conceived that addresses all the above considerations. ​

item.title: Alignment on the fly and removing motion and focus blur from pattern images collected during alignment on the fly
item.author: Sivaraman, Ram
item.summary: In all systems (tools) used for defect detection, defect classification and film and CD parameter determination, the wafer is aligned to one or both (x and y) axes of the stage prior to making any measurements on the wafer. To be able to align the wafer, pattern matching is performed between a unique feature in the field of view and a template saved in the recipe. One of the key metrics of the tool is the throughput (number of wafers that can be inspected in 1 hour) and to be able to achieve a high throughput, images can be collected for pattern matching before the stage settles down. However images collected when stage move is still in progress or is settling after the end of a move have both motion and focus blur. Such images cannot be used for pattern matching. This algorithm describes the method to remove the motion and focus blur from these images so that pattern matching can be performed on them. ​

item.title: Small-Angle X-Ray Scattering Tomographic Imaging
item.author: Sezginer, Apo
item.summary: We propose calculating a 3-dimensional map of electron density from small-angle x-ray scattering data. This method is intended to accompany -not replace- model-based CD metrology.

item.title: Lithography Process Control using Focus and Dose Metrology: Modeless Approach
item.author: Volkovich, Roie
item.summary:
In this work we present metrology measurements method based on modeless approach to allow accurate and robust measurements of scanner focus and dose values, and preclude the need for using optimized OCD model and libraries. Measurements were performed using different technologies with A500LCM and SpectraShape tools, and measured on different targets i.e. design rule targets with different line/space ration and pitch size, and on special design focus sensitive targets named focus offset targets.

The FEM model generated based on novel modeless algorithm which mimic the error deriving from OCD model approximation.

​

item.title: Managing the Impact of Evolving SIMD Architectures with Lightweight Abstraction Layers
item.author: Russell, Paul
item.summary: ​​​​Description of a proven methodology for abstracting SIMD architecture details to enable easier migration of code bases between different CPU architectures while retaining the performance benefits of SIMD.​

item.title: Collector Test Stand for RAPID 7XX LPP EUV Source Development
item.author: Kuritsyn, Alexey
item.summary: ​In this paper, we will report measurements of the debris generated by the Xenon drum-based laser produced plasma EUV source, review first mirror (collector) damage mechanisms and protection techniques, discuss limitations of an exisiting test stand and present a layout for a new Collector Test Stand (CTS). First results from the CTS are expected to be presented at the KLA-Tencor Engineering Conference.

item.title: Simulations in WIN to Support New Product Development Architecture and Specifications
item.author: Lange, Steve

item.title: Vanquish Thermal Rack Controls Modeling
item.author: Kaveh, Farro
item.summary: The current study presents an innovative method to model the Vanquish Thermal Rack control system using a lumped parameter modeling approach, and use of field data for model tuning, to assess the performance of the control system, especially in presence of the optional AMC filters, which add to the thermal inertia of the system. No similar studies are known to have been carried out at KT in the past to quantitatively predict the behavior of such thermal systems. ​

item.title: A New Analytics Approach Using High-Dimensional and Large-Scale Data from KLA-Tencor Tools
item.author: Chang, Wei
item.summary: ​In this paper, we give an overview of statistical learning and data mining with focus on techniques to solve high dimensional and large scale problems. We then use examples to demonstrate in new ways not previously addressed on how to leverage high dimensional and large scale data analytics to assist engineers to solve defect classification and tool matching problems.

item.title: Phase Grating Spectral Purity Filter for 7XX EUV Actinic Reticle Inspection System
item.author: Wang, Daimian
item.summary: We have developed phase grating spectral purity filter (SPF) for suppression of laser radiation from laser-produced plasma (LPP) EUV light source for actinic EUV reticle inspection. The SPF is binary grating on Mo/Si multilayer mirrors with pitch 50-400 um, groove depth 250-290 nm, and duty ratio of 1:1. The measured laser suppression factor in prototype planar samples is higher than 1000, and the loss of EUV reflectivity is less than 10%. ​

item.title: From where did that noise come? Understanding limits to tool sensitivity
item.author: Stokowski, Stan
item.summary: I present methods of analyzing noise to separate and measure various noise contributors to an inspection system. As an example, I show results from a 6xx mask inspection tool. In addition, I discusss and show results relating to nuisance/false detections in the presence of system noise and object variations.​

item.title: An Experiment-Based Photo-Contamination Model for Tesla
item.author: Taylor, Boyd
item.summary: ​The WIN N+2 BBP tool, Tesla, will use a shorter wavelength spectrum (190-260 nm). The photo-contamination risks of the Tesla broadband (TBB) spectrum increase relative to WIN BBP N and N+1 tools (Vanquish and Elise) due to the shorter wavelengths. The photo-contamination control specifications rely on the photo-contamination model which links the TBB light irradiance, contaminant concentration and time to the transmittance loss. However, the empirical photo-contamination model used for the N and N+1 BBP tools no longer applies to Tesla due to the shorter wavelength. To test the photo-contamination model, series of controlled experiments were conducted on dedicated bench setups. The contamination effects of organic, inorganic and siloxane contaminants versus oxygen concentration have been studied. The experimental results demonstrated that excited oxygen cleaning is more effective for Tesla than the N and N+1 BBP tools, and that oxygen concentration plays a central role in inorganic and siloxane photo-contamination.

item.title: Ultra Clean Vacuum Contamination Control
item.author: Tahmaspur, Mohamed
item.summary:
Ultra Clean Vacuum is required for the long-term operation of EUV Optics. Both molecular and particulate contamination must be minimized in EUV UCV environment. Traditional cleaning process for vacuum Utilizing ultra-clean components and a vacuum pumping system does not constitute Ultra Clean Vacuum[S1] . [S2] To achieve UCV, the outgassed contaminants within the vacuum system must be transported away from the critical surfaces by means of a continuous flow of a purge gas. Additionally, back-streamed contamination from the vacuum pumping system must be prevented. Particulate control is required on critical surfaces. Therefore, it is inevitable that achieving UCV will require significant departure from traditional vacuum systems.

[S1]Be consistent in capitalization.

[S2]Exclamation mark!!!

​

item.title: Increasing Our Customer’s Fab Yield through KT Product Data Analytics
item.author: Gutierrez, Joseph
item.summary: ​This paper makes business cases for integrated data analytics in WIN Wafer Inspection Systems to increase our customer’s fab yield. It also highlights use cases that can be realized. We can provide differential solutions to our customers by developing techniques in data analytics to analyze and communicate all WIN information more effectively. Effective use of information can help our customers lead to faster yield learning, discovering process issues, and improve their cost of ownership.

item.title: UV and VUV metrology to support Laser Sustained plasma technology development
item.author: Shchemelinin, Anatoly
item.summary: In this presentation we describe our approach to spectrophotometry and calibration services necessary for support of further development of Broadband Plasma wafer inspection systems.

item.title: Edge Profile Metrology for Trough-Silicon Via stacked wafers
item.author: Jahanbin, Sina
item.summary:
​Through-silicon via (TSV) is a high performing technique in which vertical interconnect accesses (VIAs) are completely passing through a silicon wafer or die, and is set to become the preferred technique for 3D IC manufacturing. This technique requires stacking a device wafer on top of a carrier wafer for grinding and etching the device wafer to expose TSV connections.

In recent years, edge inspection and metrology of wafers which are thinned and bonded to carrier wafers has emerged as an important use case for both memory and logic costumers. Current solutions for edge metrology cannot handle bonded wafers since bonded wafers do not have standard edge profile shapes. In practice, their edge profiles cover a wide variety of non-standard shapes that deviate greatly from the SEMI M73 EP model. The device and carrier wafers can be non-concentric yielding samples with widely varying edge-profiles at different locations on the wafer. The edges can be very rough and also have significant protrusions. Further, the glue for bonding the wafers may produce artifacts. As such, a high-speed, robust algorithm is required to handle image variations and throughput requirements, and make accurate measurements of interest.

The paper describes an algorithm for the inspection of edge profiles for the bonded wafers by reusing the VisEdge architecture without affecting its current throughput. The input edge profile images are shadowgrams created by backlighting the wafer with white collimated light. The image is binarized, morphologically cleaned, various device and carrier edges are detected using a robust-method, and then appropriate attributes are computed. The algorithm has been deployed at major customer sites since March 2013, and has met all specifications.

item.title: KTCMS: A Design for a Customizable Carrier Management System
item.author: Craig, Tom
item.summary: Complex software systems are frequently characterized by high costs and long times-to-market​ no only in their original implementations, but in the inability to evolve as markets and technologies drive new and changing requirements. The KLA-Tencor Carrier Management Services (KTCMS) is a core component of the Nexus common software platform. It's design is scalable, containing complexity in such a way as to allow customer-specific customizations without affecting default system behavior. KTCMS defines a new language, XML State Machine Definition Language (XSMDL), that models system behavior. XSMDL is non-procedural; it describes what system behavior is without regard to how it is implemented. Benefits to KLA-Tencor include reduced time-to-market, improved robustness, and reduced service costs. Customer satisfaction is elevated as KTCMS and Nexus provide a common and consistent set of behaviors across a broad array of KLA-Tencor products.

item.title: Real-time network architecture for metrology platforms
item.author: Perry, Dor

item.title: FEA modeling of contrained-layer-damped optics plate with Prony viscoelastic materials.
item.author: McMurtry, John
item.summary:
Modeling of constrained-layer-damped optics plate structures is described, with experimental results. Creo Simulate (Pro/Mechanica) and Ansys results are compared. Ansys allows use of Prony series representations of viscoelastic materials used in the constraining layer to provide shear damping in the structure. Simple test structures are modeled with experimental verification. Some results of actual complicated structure are also verified by modeling.

Modal analyses are presented for the test and actual approximations of the structures, and random response analyses to realistic input vibration and acoustic loading spectra are shown, with a goal of showing a simple methodology to predict structural dynamics response, helping to build confidence in the structural design of inspection systems. ​

item.title: Laser Dark Field Imaging of Nano-defects
item.author: Radnaev, Alexander
item.summary: We report on implementation of Laser Dark Field imaging of nano-defects for eDR-7xxx Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) platform. The wafer-roughness limited laser illumination imaging system allows for location and imaging of defects down to 18 nm at high throughput. This enables SEM review of defects inspected at next generation optical unpatterned wafer inspectors such as Surfscan SP5.​

item.title: Accu-Ray: the Deterministic Real-time Optical Selection Optimization System for Broadband Flood Illumination System
item.author: Chen, Grace
item.summary: Accu-Ray is a system designed to determine the optimal illumination scheme for flood based imaging system. The key innovation of Accu-Ray is to probe the wafer one angle at time independently. This process creates basis data which can be combined numerically to predict the inspection performance of any types of illumination scheme allowed for the system. The results of Accu-Ray provide visual representations of wafer response at different illumination configurations and aid users in creating recipes with optimal illumination setting. To enable field adoption, Accu-Ray is designed with focus on time-to result, so that the optimal illumination scheme can be discovered within a day. In addition, the data from Accu-ray is effective for real-time new aperture discovery, which shortens the gap-closure from months to days. ​

item.title: Corporate Technology Optical Design Services
item.author: Vollrath, Wolfgang
item.summary: The purpose of this paper is to introduce the recently established Corporate Technology Optical Design Services group (CorpTech ODS) and its capabilities to a broad audience of KT engineers and demonstrate its potential and capabilities by a selection of representative examples. Prior to the move to CorpTech, the group was part of RAPID Engineering Germany at KLA-Tencor MIE in Germany.​

item.title: ENZARIS: Extended Nijboer--Zernike Phase Retrieval In-Situ
item.author: Vollrath, Wolfgang
item.summary:
For a complex optical system comprising e.g. an objective, tube lenses, relay optics, folding mirrors, \dots\ the optical performance is typically only known for the individual components by various kinds of acceptance test data and protocols. Based on these data it is normally very difficult,in practice mostly impossible, to get quantitative optical performance data for the full optical track as mounted and assembled in the tool.

ENZARIS was a CTO funded project initially together with the Technical University of Delft in the Netherlands for in-situ wavefront aberration retrieval from through-focus stacks of pinhole images. The software for phase retrieval, also called ENZARIS, is now available for application. The poster explains the theory and shows first results.​

item.title: Simulation of TIS related to Optical System Tolerances
item.author: Vollrath, Wolfgang
item.summary:
TIS -- Tool Induced Shift -- is one of the most crucial optical performance parameters for overlay (ARCHER) or pattern placement (IPRO5) metrology. Assuming a perfect symmetrical illumination then, in case of tool issues with TIS, the root cause is in almost all cases related to asymmetries in the imaging objective. The strongest and most frequent occurring impact on TIS comes from residual lateral misalignments of lens elements in the objective. Such misalignments cause what is called axial coma which results in a left-right asymmetry in line image intensity profiles by which in turn the effective line position in the image is shifted.

While with optical design programs like Zemax or Code V it is a standard procedure to calculate the effect of optical tolerances on axial coma, TIS is not an aberration which can be directly addressed.

By a combination of optical tolerance analysis with the KT MIE proprietary optical design code O1 and a subsequent evaluation of the O1 data by a dedicated Matlab script it is now possible to tolerate an optical system directly for TIS in a very efficient and straight forward way.​

item.title: Novel Direct Self Assembly OVL Target Design
item.author: Yohanan, Raviv
item.summary: Direct Self assebly (DSA) is one of the most promising "Alternative lithography" techniuqe which has the potential to reduce today immersion lithography and double patterning resolution in order to extend Lithography node beyond N10. this paper is based on KLA and IMEC DSA OVL target design collaboration and suggesting novel OVL Target Design concept to address DSA target Design challenge.​

item.title: 3D Measurement of BGA- and CSP-packages: ball height measurement of small pitch packages by combining stereo-vision and phase-shifting (3DWave)
item.author: Van der Burgt, Maarten
item.summary: In the new generation ICOS Component Inspector tools we combine stereo vision and phase shifting to measure the ball height and the substrate coplanarity of ball grid array (BGA) and chip scale packages (CSP) with a small ball pitch. The sinusoidal fringe projection and phase shifting method replaces a method based on projected laser lines, which has become inadequate for the current requirements. We discuss the fringe projection method, the improvements, possibilities and limitations.

item.title: Analytical Techniques to Drive Successful Failure Analysis, Vendor Management and Materials Selections for Inspection Systems
item.author: Rose, Garry
item.summary: ​Leveraging the learning done with these analytical instruments, K-T now has developed a deeper understanding of light induced surface contamination and damage of materials, ranging from optical elements, wafer, reticles, detectors and TDI's. And along the way we have developed top notch knowledge and a suite of high performing analytical instruments and techniques to provide detailed chemical characterization, surface chemical characterization, nano-scale feature analysis, and thin film characterization.

item.title: Wave-optical analysis of a microlens-based confocal bump-inspection module (COSSAP)
item.author: Buettner, Alexander
item.summary: We discuss a wave-optical model of the COSSAP confocal module accurate enough to predict complex Z-response curves for different microlens array and objective lens parameters.​

item.title: Overlay metrology with 2-beam imaging
item.author: Levinski, Vladimir
item.summary: An innovative approach to imaging overlay metrology, 2-beam overlay metrology, is described. The potential of this method for improving imaging overlay metrology performance is outlined in this abstract, with the prototype results and “learned lessons” to be included in the full paper. ​

item.title: Proposal for spectral analysis tool for the inspection of biological cells.
item.author: Christiaanse, Johan
item.summary: ​A proposal for the development of an instrument for the spectral analysis of biological cells, that will provide scientists extended tools for the research of biological cells and disease mechanisms.

item.title: RAPID Diagnostic Software Architecture using LabVIEW
item.author: Vella, Eric
item.summary: RAPID has adopted a unique architecture for integrating diagnostics and calibrations into the overall software system. Diagnostic software is deliberately kept separate from inspection software, running on a separate computer and operating system. A layered image acquisition system enables diagnostic programs to control system hardware through the same interface used by inspection software. Diagnostic software is written in LabVIEW, a data-driven graphical programming language. This paper presents an overview of this software architecture and discusses some of its advantages and disadvantages. ​

item.title: Modeling of Waveplate Artifacts and Misalignment using Zemax
item.author: Flock, Klaus
item.summary: A novel waveplate design is presented. A detailed Zemax model of the waveplate is compared to a standard algebraic model​ of the waveplate. An improved system model is presented that retains computational simplicity while improving matching to the Zemax model.

item.title: Improving Supplier Quality and Reliability through innovative sharing of best practices
item.author: Kasmalkar, Maheendra
item.summary: With increasing design outsourcing to suppliers, WIN has seen increased issues with quality and reliability affecting customer satisfaction, delayed programs, delayed shipments, ineffective support in field. Root causing these issues led WIN to an innovative idea - Supplier's engineering is an extension of WIN engineering. This idea has been implemented in form of WIN Supplier Quality-Reliability initiative to develop long-lasting productive relationships between WIN and supplier. Lessons learned by WIN over several years are being shared with strategic suppliers in form of best practices, design rules, problem solving methodologies, manufacturing processes. In return, suppliers are being held to the same metrics and standards that WIN engineers are held to. Since FY13, this initiative has been implemented at 6 critical suppliers. We are already seeing improvements in supplier's design and manufacturing processes for better predictability of final product. At the same time, WIN design engineers are learning skills for successfully managing suppliers thus making them ready for future jobs in Engineering management and program management. Lessons learned from this initiative are being documented to establish a POR for future engineering management of suppliers. ​

item.title: Active Sampling
item.author: Banerjee, Saibal
item.summary: Active Sampling, a WIG System of Systems application involving the use of both the Optical Inspector and the SEM Review tool to discover defects of interest and filter nuisances in a fast and effective way, is discussed. The various stages of the Active Sampling prototype are detailed, with particular emphasis on the algorithmic methods used in every stage. Preliminary results on customer data, showing the promise and efficacy of this application are also presented.

item.title: Photo-induced Contamination of Optical Elements in a Reticle or Photomask Inspection System with 193nm Illumination
item.author: Garcia, Edgardo
item.summary: ​Photocontamination is the physicochemical process by which undesired photoactivated and/or photodecomposed organic or inorganic chemistries are deposited on an optical surface. Such processes increase significantly with shorter wavelengths. For 193nm light the photocontamination problem can be 10-100x fold worse (depending on the molecule) than previous longer wavelenght systems. We'll discuss the evlolution of contamination control and impacts to systems, and how to measure and predict the impact to tool performance.

item.title: High Sensitivity Mask Writer Accuracy Monitoring on 1D Pattern Using RAPID Teron Inspection System
item.author: Cong, Ge
item.summary: Mask writer accuracy is an important parameter for photomask and wafer manufacturing. In this paper, we describe a highly sensitive mask writer pattern shift defect detection system. The approach is based on RAPID Teron platform, requiring reticle post-OPC design database. The proposed approach starts with searching database for 1D patterns and measure the CDs along these 1D patterns in the optical image. We then analyze the CD profile, searching for a particular pattern shift signature caused by mask writer error. Data showed that we could have good defection accuracy for the pattern shift defects down to the 3nm level.​

item.title: High Speed Laser Power Modulation and Large Particle Monitor Subsystem (LPM) in unpatterned Wafer Inspection
item.author: Wolters, Christian
item.summary: ​LPM is a method to dynamically attenuate the laser power as the beam scans over large particles in order to avoid particle damage and wafer contamination through secondary particle generation, and has become a critical competitive differentiator for the SP3 and SP5 unpatterned wafer inspection systems. LPM detects the proximity of particles during the wafer inspection in real time by a designated sensing beam and laser power is attenuated within 300 ns using an advanced coincidence algorithms running on the analog front end FPGA. Post processing routines restore inspection data in the attenuated regions and provide for dynamic range extension using attenuated and sensing information. The paper will discuss experimental findings of particle damage during inspection, LPM design and principle of operation, applications, and practical limitations.​

item.title: How to determine lifetime of EUV, VUV and DUV optical elements of Reticle and wafer Inspection Systems
item.author: Delgado, Gil
item.summary: Optics damage and Photocontamination (PC) of optical elements is one of the main reasons for optical systems to reach premature lifetimes. Optics Damage and Photo-induced organic and inorganic contamination of optical elements induced by EUV,VUV, DUV and IR not only threaten lifetime of sensitive optics but also create a host of limiting performance issues including system instability, matching and downtime. For example, contamination of the illumination and projection optics is one of the primary sources of light loss and instability. A critical necessity of optical inspection systems is long lifetime survivability under continuous and high fluence irradiation. The desired goal for inspections systems under operation is 10 yrs with no changes in optical performance and minimal PM or downtime. This imposes many demanding challenges. This talk will give an overview on the main challenges encountered in inspection systems and on strategies to design for desired lifetimes.​

item.title: Laser Crystal Degradation Compensation
item.author: Genis, Pat
item.summary: ​Higher tool sensitivity requirements drive laser light sources to higher power and shorter wavelength. At higher powers, the nonlinear crystal used for frequency conversion within the laser exhibit damage at a faster rate impacting the output laser beam parameters, tool utilization, and uniformity of tool performance. Two techniques are presented to circumvent the fast degradation: ordered recursive discrete shifting and preferential direction micro-stepping.

item.title: A Computational Metrology Target Designer
item.author: Gready, David
item.summary: Below the 20 nm node, lithographic patterning process control requirements are driving accuracy as the main metric of metrology performance. Scatterometry overlay (SCOL) is slowly emerging as a contender to the mainstay of imaging overlay metrology primarily due to target design. With their smaller pitches and grating over grating geometry, SCOL targets potentially improve process compatibility which correlates strongly with metrology accuracy. However, the challenge of designing targets which are simultaneously process compatible, highly precise and small enough to fit in die requires searching a large parameter space in geometric design and metrology tool mode of operation (“recipe”). Furthermore, the search requires covering an even larger parameter space of potential stack and process variations which may occur unintentionally or by design. This abstract describes a computational method to predict metrology performance over a large parameter space of target geometry and metrology setup permutations - a methodology expected to become enabling for overlay metrology at 14 nm design rule nodes and below. ​

item.title: Phase-sensitive imaging for defect inspection and review
item.author: Daneshpanah, Mehdi
item.summary: ​​​​​​​​​​​​​We explore using quantitative phase imaging in reticle inspection and review. Our goals are: to increase the signal-to-noise ratio of the defect signal; to detect different defect types at one focus setting; and to predict defect printability under scanner imaging conditions. ​

item.title: X-Ray Mapping for Semiconductor Defect Review
item.author: Sears, Christopher

item.title: An electron-beam review system with super-high resolutions benefited from an energy-filtering mono-chromator
item.author: Jiang, Xinrong

item.title: Design for Product Lifetime Extension Tolerance During Product Development
item.author: Tomasch, Gregory
item.summary: This paper will describe how the ever-increasing service life of KLA-Tencor’s products presents challenges to the Service Business and how design consideration in development phase can help support product lifetime extendibility. ​

item.title: Improving PWG Tool Matching by Increasing Accuracy of IPD Measurements using a Self-Matching Method
item.author: Zheng, Jeff
item.summary: A self-matching method has been developed for PWG metrology tools. Improve the absolute accuracy of IPD measurements using the self-matching method, ensuring the tool-to-tool matching. The IPD site-2-site matching between two tools has been dramatically improved, from 10nm to 1nm. This process also improves manufacturing flexibility and cross site serviceability. ​

item.title: Breaking Rotational Symmetry in Electron Optical Systems
item.author: Sears, Christopher

item.title: Laser Hot Testing of White LEDs for Improved Measurement of Color and Efficacy
item.author: McCord, Mark
item.summary: We have developed a technology using laser heating to more quickly and accurately measure the color and lumens output from high brightness white LEDs. A bench has been constructed to prove feasibility. Results will be shown from a customer collaboration demonstrating the performance of the technology.​

item.title: 'Virtual Inspector' – An Architectural and Use Case Overview
item.author: Bhaskar, Chetana
item.summary: ​​​​​In this paper, we will cover architectural and use case aspects of the Virtual Inspector which has been developed over the last decade in WIN engineering and has been widely used internally and now over a half-dozen installations in fabs worldwide. ​The VI broadens our yield solution domain while enabling new feature development​.

item.title: Electrostatic Discharge Investigative Tools and Methods
item.author: George, Alan
item.summary: Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) has long been known to pose various problems during the manufacturing of semiconductors. Recent reliability problems on FaST Tools running at an important customer were suspected to be caused by ESD that occurred during wafer loading or unloading. This paper describes the experimental path that was followed to investigate the problems as well as the tools and techniques used to do so. ESD caused by the tribo-electric effect was shown to be the root cause of the problems. Equipment was configured to measure the ESD events and to correlate them in time to entries in the tool logs. This equipment was installed at the customer site to confirm ESD as the source of the problems. The remedies applied to mitigate the ESD are also described. ​

item.title: Novel concept for scanner focus metrology: focus offset targets
item.author: Levinski, Vladimir
item.summary: Focus metrology with multiple symmetric focus offset targets of the same pitch in the range 1.2∙Pmin

item.title: Characterization of Discharge Produced Plasmas for use in EUV Reticle Inspection
item.author: Umstadter, Karl
item.summary:
Extreme ultraviolet light (EUV) holds strong promise as a source for producing the ever-smaller components of tomorrow’s integrated circuits. EUV sources will be used to produce light for both lithography and at-wavelength (actinic) inspection of EUV masks. To inspect EUV masks, KLA-Tencor needs a 13.5nm source that will be reliable and bright-enough to inspect a mask in several hours.

A discharge-produced-plasma (DPP) was initially considered for use in the 7XX tool to provide extreme ultra-violet (EUV) light for imaging and inspection purposes. A commercial source [1] has been available for several years and is used by all EUV developers as a source – but as-is, it is not suitable for 24/7/365 mask inspection. We have developed three test benches to characterize the commercial source for brightness, reliability and contamination. In addition, we completed a program to extend the use of this source and mitigate the debris it generates. These benches continue to operate for risk reduction within the 7XX program and the methods first developed here have been adapted for use on laser-produced-plasma (LPP) based illumination test benches.​

item.title: Dependence of contamination rates on key parameters in EUV and 193nm optics
item.author: Delgado, Gil
item.summary:
We have investigated the intensity dependence of the carbon deposition rates produced by exposure to in-band 13.5 nm light in the presence of hydrocarbon and compare these carbon growth rates with 193 nm atmospheric rates. Measured rates, theoretical models and some system analysis indicate that193nm radiation contamination rates are higher than rates for EUV radiation.

We also point out the difference in design and conjecture that 193 inspection system is as challenging if not more that an EUV inspection system.

​

item.title: The evolution of particle contamination control in e-beam review tools (eDR-7xxx)
item.author: Harb, Salam
item.summary: Overview to the particle contamination control works conducted in for the eDR-7xxx tool to improve PWP margins. Examples for some of the particle source and transport mechanisms and design work to address and mitigate will be presented in this manuscript.

item.title: 2DBPR CD Dynamic Precision in Small Spot Measurement
item.author: Fu, Jiyou
item.summary: We report on 2DBPR (2-Dimensional Beam Profile Reflectometer) CD (Critical Dimension) dynamic precision in small spot measurement. The dynamic precision is the 3sgima of the CD values measured by the system with 10 wafer load and unloads. Unlike other optical CD measurement modules whose beam samples a moderate size, typically 15~40μm diameter [1], 2DBPR system samples much smaller size, typically ~5 μm diameter. With 9~64 times less sampling area, the CD parameters measured by 2DBPR system are of much less statistically averaged values for the limited number of the CD features. Therefore, 2DBPR measurement is intrinsically more sensitive to wafer uniformity and capable of detecting local variations. The measurement data also shows that 2DBPR CD dynamic precision is greatly dependent on the x/y/z placement repeatability. We have developed several approaches to improve the dynamic precision by reducing the uncertainty in x/y/z placement, and also propose some ideas for further improvement.​

item.title: 193-nm laser-induced optical damage of fused silica
item.author: Zare, David
item.summary: Laser-induced optical damage of fused silica is the focus of this presentation. Optics damage is defined as the condition or set of conditions where light causes optical changes such that the system specifications are violated. Conditions leading to damage are presented in this work by examples from RAPID’s 193 nm Laser light source and Fused Silica glass. Different damage mechanisms, such as Laser Induced Absorption, Laser Induced Birefringence, Compaction and Rarefaction, and Laser Induced fluorescents will be described. Further we demonstrate a methodology to isolate and measure damage to the bulk material and coatings with data collected over several years. The uniqueness of KLA’s light sources means that this data is available nowhere else, and in the process an industry leading set of knowledge has been developed that continues to drive all of our optics supplier’s requirements and knowledge of the quality of their optics.​

item.title: Predicting Complex Multi-step Semiconductor Processing using Wafer Geometry
item.author: Sinha, Jaydeep
item.summary: ​The geometry of silicon wafers that are used as substrates for integrated circuits is critical for process control during semiconductor device manufacturing and ultimately for device yield. Process-induced overlay and defocus errors are a growing problem in meeting the ever-tightening lithography requirements for integrated circuit production. While uniform process-induced shape is easily corrected, non-uniform shape across the wafer is much more problematic, often resulting in non-correctable overlay errors. Flatness of a wafer changes with process steps. Wafer flatness is only 30% of the overall Lithography defocus budget. This paper will explore the relationship of wafer geometry and in and out of plane displacements on a Lithography chuck.

item.title: DIC Inspection Mode for VNAND
item.author: Beier, Brooke
item.summary: Major flash memory manufacturers started in recent years to develop vertical flash (also known as VNAND) to address the increasing difficulties they face in manufacturing the traditional planar flash at increasingly shrinking design rules. This vertical integration creates the necessity of detecting buried defects at depths up to 2 um or more. KLA-Tencor introduced the 3D1 tool to address the need to inspect and detect buried defects, and that was possible by using wavelengths longer than what is used in traditional inspection tools. In addition to the implementation of longer wavelengths in order to penetrate the depths of the VNAND structure, other techniques are being investigated to aid in the detection and localization of buried defects. Differential Interference Contrast (DIC) is investigated as a means of providing depth discrimination in the inspection and review of VNAND wafers. ​

item.title: Single-photon Damage of Fused Silica with Deep Ultraviolet Sub bandgap Broadband CW Light
item.author: Panzer, Matthew
item.summary: Both photon energies and fluences on optical components continue to increase with the push toward operating into the deep ultraviolet (DUV, 190-300 nm) and vacuum ultraviolet (<190 nm) spectrum with high throughput in future generation KLA-Tencor tools such as the WIN Tesla Broad-Band Plasma platform. These high photon energies and fluences lead to an increased risk of photo-induced changes in the optical material properties such as the index of refraction (compaction and rarefaction) and absorption, posing substantial risks to tool performance. For transmissive DUV systems, fused silica is an essential and often unavoidable material due to its combination of excellent optical properties, low cost, and manufacturability. However, the amorphous network structure of fused silica makes it particularly prone to photo‑induced degradation through a variety of complex mechanisms. Ensuring that optical components meet the performance requirements for up to 15 year life often requires physics-based models to extrapolate limited accelerated test data. In this work we characterize the compaction behavior of fused silica (Su401, Su501, HPFS 8655) under exposure to broad band CW irradiation with wavelengths down to 185 nm. We find that all the fused silica tested show similar compaction behavior (density increases) with reciprocity in the one-photon dose, indicating the presence of a one-photon compaction mechanism with light below the bandgap, and yielding compaction rates of 42-63, 33-81, and 39-85 ppm/(GJ/cm2) at 193 nm for Su401, Su501, HPFS 8655, respectively, which are insensitive to H2 content and appear weakly dependent on the OH content of the glass. The compaction depends strongly on VUV edge and temperature, consistent with an Urbach absorption process. An Urbach absorption model extracts the wavelength dependence of the damage, yielding values that appear to account for the anomalous behavior in low-fluence 193 nm laser testing. ​

item.title: Shock Response Spectra (SRS) for Packaging Development and Auditing
item.author: Nicely, Daniel
item.summary:
Introduction:
As KT product become more complex understanding the fragility can reduce the overall risk incurred in both interplant handling and transportation. There are analytical and testing techniques available to assess the product's ability to survive the minimum shock and vibration the product will experience. It is important to investigate the survivability early on in the product development where many times simple design modifications can be employed that will increase the ruggedness. A lack of this understanding can have the following affects:

  • Poor reliability
  • Higher warranty costs
  • Higher transportation and packaging costs

Because of the high value of KT tools sacrificing the first prototype to determine fragility can be extremely costly, delay the program and may not actually provide information that relates exactly to the in use or shipping environments. This presentation will cover a technique that is being employed to minimize the risk of shipping damage without destructive testing.

​

item.title: Nanoengineered charge-drain film for electron-optical MEMS in the REBL e-beam column
item.author: Tong, William
item.summary: We developed a charge-drain film composed of Mo oxide nanoparticles embedded in a Al2O3 matrix. The resulting film has customizable resistivity, high dielectric strength, and can be deposited isotropically onto high aspect-ratio MEMS features by ALD. ​

item.title: Prediction of Local Stress on Product Wafer Using Local Curvature of Wafer Shape
item.author: Veeraraghavan, Sathish
item.summary: Multiple thin film deposition and strip steps are central to most semiconductor device fabrication processes. The residual stresses in these thin films can induce both in-plane and out-of-plane distortions to the wafer1 that can be measured using wafer metrology tool such as PWG. These residual stresses can vary spatially across the wafer and the residual stress distributions can change between lithography steps. This can result in non-correctable overlay errors in the lithography processes2,3. In order to develop strategies for minimizing overlay errors due to residual stress-induced distortion, there is a critical need for techniques that allow the distributions of residual stresses in deposited thin films to be characterized with high spatial resolution. In this paper, the application of established analytical methods for extracting local residual stress from wafer geometry measurements (shape) is investigated. 3-D finite-element models were used to simulate wafer shapes resulting from non-uniform residual stress distributions in thin-films. Based on these finite element simulations, the effectiveness of the analytical techniques were assessed and it was demonstrated that local mean curvature of the wafer shape is a simple metric that can be used to predict local residual stress variation across the wafer. The simulations also demonstrated that when residual stresses varied over scales of tens of millimeters that high spatial resolution (<1 mm) shape measurements were required in order to accurately predict local residual stress. ​

item.title: Relationship between Wafer Geometry and Lithography Overlay: Evolution of Finite Element Modeling for Complex Multi-step Semiconductor Processing
item.author: Vukkadala, Pradeep
item.summary: Wafer shape is the deviation of the median surface of a wafer from a reference plane in a free state [1]. Changes in wafer shape can be caused by the deposition of residually stressed thin films [2] (oxides, poly, metals), thermal residual stresses induced during rapid thermal processing [3,4], and mechanical damage induced during Chemical Mechanical Polishing (CMP). Residual stress in deposited thin films deforms the wafer causing wafer shape changes and in-plane (i.e., within the wafer plane) distortion. The in-plane pattern distortion will result in overlay errors, some of which may be uncorrectable, and will usually be linked to measurable changes in wafer shape. The objective of this work is to establish the relationship between residual stress induced wafer shape to overlay using three approaches. First, the relationship between overlay and wafer shape is established for a single thin film with uniform stress on Si substrate using an analytical model. Second, a similar relationship is established for a single thin film with non-uniform stress using a two-step finite element model. One of the limiting case of the two-step finite element model is for a sharp local stress variation near the edge of the wafer through etching high stress Nitride film. To address this limiting case a third model, a four-step finite element model was developed to accurately simulate the wafer processing. The three models will be described in detail and illustrated with examples. ​

item.title: RAPID Autofocus Systems Evolving Requirements and Architectures
item.author: Wright, Michael
item.summary: ​Paper surveys the history of RAPID autofocus system development over the last decade, describing numerous improvements in the areas of servo design, focus algorithms, acoustic excitation reduction, mechanical design, etc. Stresses careful consideration of requirements and use of a flexible, multidiplinary design approach to optimizing performance. Presents details of most recent algorithm change which reduces D-D relative focus error by a 3-5 factor.

item.title: Nanoengineered charge-drain film for electron-optical MEMS in the REBL e-beam column
item.author: Tong, William
item.summary: We have developed a new type of charge drain film made of a material that has high dielectric strength, customizable resistivity, and depositable by an isotropic technique to coat high aspect ratio MEMS features. It is composed of nanoclusters of MoO3-x, a conductive metal oxide, embedded in Al2O3. The film enabled our electron optical MEMS to operate in its electron rich envronment without any charging for many months, yielding high resolution patterns. This work won a R&D 100 award for 2013. ​

item.title: Simulated Scanner Environment for Offline Reticle Inspection Development
item.author: Blecher, Joe

item.title: Metrology tool for drive laser characterization advances 7xx EUV source development
item.author: Liu, Ye
item.summary: The EUV mask inspection tool plays a vital role for a successful adoption of EUV lithography into volume Production. Laser produced plasma ("LPP") EUV source is regarded to be the most attractive light sources. Drive laser with optimum parameters, such as the laser pulse energy, pulse duration, and beam quality, is key element in the design of LPP system. These optimized laser parameters have to be carefully characterized. Various innovative methods were employed to accurately monitor critical performance indicators in real time. These data can extend the understanding of how laser-source parameters impact EUV source performance.​

item.title: Signal Response Metrology
item.author: Pandev, Stilian
item.summary: ​This paper will present the Signal Response Metrology and try to provide evidence for the value of information content analysis and machine learning in Focus, Dose and CD measurements, target design, tool matching and calibration, system design optimization.

item.title: Defect Inspection Using a Standard Reference Die
item.author: Chen, Hong
item.summary: Defect inspection using a standard reference die (SRD) is initially developed to close the gap for single die reticle inspection. The major challenge in SRD is color variation and misalignment. This paper presented an approach, dynamic compensation, to reduce color variation and improve alignment. Results show that DC performs much better than 4 point LaGrange in terms of noise reduction. ​

item.title: The REBL Compact Gun and Column Optics Design and Modeling for High Volume Manufacturing
item.author: Brodie, Alan
item.summary:
Otical lithography has been the mainstay sustaining Moore's law in the patterning of nano/micro-electronic circuits. To meet the demand for device shrinkage down to 16nm half-pitch features and beyond, advanced lithography technologies are being investigated: Extreme ultra-violet lithography (EUVL), directed self-assembly (DSA), nano-imprint lithography (NIL) and multiple electron beam lithography.

KLA-Tencor is developing reflective electron beam lithography (REBL) technology with support from DARPA and TSMC to enable maskless lithography for HVM of semiconductors at 16 nm half-pitch and beyond.[i],[ii]

The REBL column optics consists of two sections: the illumination optics and the imaging optics. An off-axis illuminating beam is merged into the optical axis of the electron beam column through a Wien (E x B) filter. This flood beam then illuminates an active area of 0.4 mm x 6.6 mm of the digital pattern generator (DPG); an electron-optical MEMS consisting of a 248 x 4096 array of individually addressable 1.6 mm pitch lenslet pixels. Through the selective application of a positive or negative electrostatic bias on the bottom of each lenslet, the electron beamlet is absorbed or reflected, respectively, by each DPG pixel. The pixelated overall image of the DPG is then demagnified by greater than 100x onto the wafer.

The use of a large area DPG reduces the limitations of traditional single electron beam lithography systems: space-charge and data rate. In the REBL system, high data rate is achieved by exposing over one million pixels in parallel, and the space-charge or Coulomb interactions are reduced by distributing the beam current over a relatively large area of 246 mm2 at 100x demagnification.

This paper will concentrate on the latest optics design of the REBL system.

item.title: XML/DITA: A New Paradigm for Developing and Publishing Structured Knowledge at KLA-Tencor using eXtensible Markup Language
item.author: Tandon, Sanjay
item.summary:
XML DITA , eXtensible Markup Language and Darwin Information Typing Application, is an innovative technology that can form a part of the mosaic of a KM solution for KLA-Tencor’s information challenge. DITA is designed for managing technical information in reusable topics or components which are stored as XML.

This paper will explore the benefits of XML DITA in the KLA-Tencor environment with study of particular use cases to reduces document development cycle time; content reuse so that engineering, manufacturing, and service can use variations of the same product content; conditional processing so that multiple variants of the content can be published for CSEs and Customers; and multichannel publishing for different UI and output types.

​

item.title: Focus quality and collection efficiency modeling on laser-sustained plasma lamp house
item.author: Oh, Sebaek
item.summary: This paper describes how to model collection efficiency and how to optimize design parameters and tolerance of Laser-sustained plasma (LSP) Lamp House in engineering perspective.
