As the lamp house consists of IR pumping optics and UV collection optics, we primarily consider pumping focus and collection efficiency as metrics for tolerance, and we explore various design parameters and investigate their tolerance sensitivity ​

item.title: Failure analysis of damaged AIT-UV collector lens assemblies
item.author: Zhang, Xinya
item.summary: Failure analysis of damaged AIT-UV collector lens assemblies was performed. Surface chemical components on damaged and undamaged areas of the lens surface were analyzed by XPS. Results interpretation and conclusion will be presented.​

item.title: Model based pattern registration for reticle metrology
item.author: Daneshpanah, Mehdi
item.summary: ​​​​​​​Mask registration error impacts intra-field wafer overlay directly and constitutes 25% of the overlay budget [1-3]. We present use of physics-based modeling for mask metrology in the IPRO5+ product line. The goals are to 1) measure registration on in-die, functional patterns of the mask rather than simple, large targets that may exhibit different registration behavior than in-die patterns, and 2) increase the number of sampling points on the mask to recover high frequency registration maps without the need to embed excessive number of large targets in the active area, and 3) allow mask shops to analyze registration hot-spots leading to wafer overlay problems after mask is manufactured. ​

item.title: Inspection-Review Defect Location Accuracy Tracking Using KLARITY Synergy
item.author: Sinha, Harsh

item.title: Water-Filled Bulbs for WIN Broadband Plasma Tools
item.author: Bezel, Ilya
item.summary: ​Water-containing bulbs were suggested and tested for the use in illuminator in WIN Broadband Plasma Tools. We demonstrate significant reduction of VUV-induced bulb damage due to efficient VUV absorption in water.

item.title: RapdIMAGE POSITIONING SYSTEM FOR ACHIEVING 50 NM IMAGE POSITION ACCURACY
item.author: Xie, Yang
item.summary: ​This paper presents the latest development of image positioning system to meet EUV blank inspection market requirement. This system has taken comprehensive approaches to reduce error sources, measure and correct errors in real time and post image position process. Quantitative error sources and reduction have been presented based on recent test results.

item.title: Sirius – Glorious Past and Bright Future
item.author: Bezel, Ilya
item.summary:
​Description of research projects and capabilities of Sirius, a scientific lamphouse for plasma studies, which has provided many insights on Plasma Sources.

Overview talk.

item.title: SPx sizing and XY location measurements (Calibration and Algo)
item.author: Chen, Leon
item.summary:
With an inspection tool that spins the wafer for defect detection, the defect measurements are made with information from the spiral tracks. The defect size and XY location have to be reconstructed based on an interpolation in between the spiral tracks. This presentation will discuss the technique and improvement used in SP1, SP2, SP3 and SP5, with the best usage of the beam profile for the accuracy required for each generation of these tools.


With the moderate requirement on the SP1 accuracy at that time, an ideal Gaussian beam shape with a nominal beam size was adequate. With the tightened up SP2 requirement, we had to actually measured the beam size at the wafer plane. With the SP3/5 requirement, we have to use the actual beam shape. This presentation will reveal the measurement of the actual beam shape on the wafer plane and its improvement to the defect sizing and XY location.​

item.title: Pupil engineering concepts for VNAND inspection
item.author: Clark, Nathan
item.summary: VNAND is a high-growth emerging market where architecture of flash memory has changed from planar to vertical. This change to a vertical structure introduces several challenges to wafer inspection, including the need to detect defects buried at depths of up to 2 μm or more from the surface. KLA-Tencor addressed the need to inspect these devices with the introduction of 3D1. This tool targets detecting buried defects using near infrared light by penetrating deeper into the VNAND devices. Among the toughest challenges facing us in detecting buried defects is the ability to detect the signal at depths of interests within the structure. For instance, the TDI may become saturated by light reflected from the surface of the device before collecting enough signal from the defect within the bulk of the structure. We use pupil engineering to address these challenges by adjusting and optimizing illumination and detection apertures. With this approach we can selectively increase the light delivered deeper into the structure while blocking light reflected from the surface, increasing tool sensitivity for buried defects. ​

item.title: Plasma size woes
item.author: Bezel, Ilya
item.summary: ​Discussion of the main challenge for collectable light power required by the roadmap of future WIN Broadband Plasma tools: keeping the plasma small. We discuss why the plasmas are of a certain size, why they grows with power, where instabilities come from, and what needs to be done to keep the plasma small.

item.title: Laser-Sustained Plasma modeling strategy
item.author: Bezel, Ilya
item.summary: ​An overview of the modeling strategy adopted by WIN Technology and WIN Engineering for description of Laser-Sustained plasmas and lamps.

item.title: Backside Autofocus Approach for EUV Reticle Inspection
item.author: Lin, Zhengcheng
item.summary:
Maintaining good focus in the presence of patterns in reticle/mask inspection is not a trivial task. Actually, it is one of the most difficult tasks when designing and building reticle inspection machines.

In 3XX and 5XX eras, optical sensor and servo based traditional autofocus was the main approach used in the reticle inspection machines. The issue associated with the traditional autofocus is that it suffers from pattern effects on dense patterns. In the last a few years, surface map based approach, namely ZCAL approach [1], was developed, which greatly improved the performance of the focus system.

In the last a couple of years, the business of EUV mask inspections gradually gains its market shares. What is needed in the EUV mask inspections (with much smaller features) is much tighter focus requirement than that of the optical masks. Although the current ZCAL approach still meet the EUV mask focus needs, tightening focus requirements leads us to look for new way for focus control.

The approach of backside autofocus is formed and designed under this circumstance specifically for EUV mask inspections. One nice thing about EUV masks is that interferograms [2] are taken for all the blank EUVs when they are made. Through the effort from Rapid Marketing, these blank interferograms would become available at the time when the corresponding patterned EUV mask is being inspected in one of the Mask Shops.

Differing from the traditional focus and ZCAL map approaches, the backside autofocus starts with measuring the heights from the backside of an EUV mask, utilizing the back and front interferograms, and then calculating the front-side mask surface heights for the purpose of run-time swath trajectory generations. In addition, there are a couple of EUV specific properties that would make the backside approach much more attractive in increasing the focus accuracy: (1) the backside mapping based approach does not have to deal with any possible patterns on an EUV mask because all the height measurements are carried out in the backside of the EUV mask, plus that the interferograms are taken when mask is still a blank yet; (2) EUV mask surface profiles, plate thickness/wedge and thermal expansion are very well controlled comparing to those of the optical masks. Therefore, the focus Z specification can be set as stringent as to range using the backside autofocus approach.​

item.title: Method of In-Situ Imaging System Wavefront Characterization
item.author: Zhang, Qiang.Q
item.summary: ​​ ​​​​​​ As the complexity of high precision optical system soars, it has become increasingly important to develop a capability to characterize the optical wavefront aberration of an imaging system as a whole on a regular basis, for monitoring the health condition of the optical system and troublesho oting, assisting optical alignment, and potentially improving the image rendering algorithm. In this study, we introduce a cost-effective in-situ wavefront retrieval method based on pinhole images collected through focus without implementing additional optical hardware. We also demonstrate the accuracy and repeatability of such method on RAPID 6xx systems in comparison to the interferometry measurement.​ ​

item.title: Lamp Cooling Design for Thermal Stress Damage Mitigation
item.author: Wang, Jincheng
item.summary: Residual stress due to thermal creep is a key contributor to lamp breakage. This effect is exacerbated at higher UV output power from arc lamps in conventional DC discharge mode and with laser sustained plasmas inside lamps due to the higher absorption of UV light in the glass which leads to increased operating temperatures. The present paper provides a way to better control and optimize lamp operating conditions, especially the temperature, thus reducing creep induced stress levels to safe limits and preventing bulb breakage. Using a combined modeling and experimental approach, safe operation temperature limits are determined to keep stress levels from increasing excessively for lamps constructed with various glass materials based on their viscosity properties. The method has been successfully implemented on VQ/D5/Elise tools and enabling lamp life time goal being met.​

item.title: Experimental Method for Measurement of the Modulation Transfer Function (MTF) for Charge Coupled Device (CCD) image Sensors.
item.author: Balakrishnan, Binu
item.summary: ​The method extends the conventional slit illumination method used to estimate Optical Transfer Function (OTF) of optical components, to measure the MTF of the CCD. The moving slit approach presented here generates a super resolution Line Spread Function (LSF) which is analyzed further to plot the MTF

item.title: DLA improvement for broadband wafer inspection systems
item.author: Zhang, Yale
item.summary: Defect location accuracy (DLA) is a key system performance spec for broadband wafer inspection system. It essentially answers the second important question for our customers: “where are the defects”. Over the past nine years, we have improved broadband wafer inspection system from 10um into 0.25um without PDA (Pixel to Design Alignment) and 0.15um with PDA. From system level budget to a detailed bug fix or algo improvement, we have taken a systematic way of product development and problem solving strategy. Several methods for DLA improvement will be discussed on this paper. Test data before and after fix as well as theoretical analysis and error budget will be presented. The technical approach to meet next DLA milestone will be discussed. ​

item.title: Systematic Defect Filtering
item.author: Zhou, Wei-Feng(Allen)
item.summary: Systematic defect filtering (SDF) is introduced to achieve both inspectability and sensitivity requirements in certain inspections. It filters false defects based on the assumption of repeatability of false defects and random distribution of real defects. It also helps to reduce the reviewing and classifying burden of the operator because the defect count decreases significantly. It’s the first plate-level algorithm developed in RAPID to make decision based on the global information of defects. ​

item.title: balakrBench level Linearity Characterization of Time Delay Integration (TDI) Camera for Design Optimization
item.author: Balakrishnan, Binu
item.summary: ​. In this paper, we discuss a unique linearity characterization tool developed and integrated to the Rapid Engineering camera test bench. The focus of this work is describing, in detail, the measurement system and methodologies we developed for extending the conventional uniformity calibration approach to the existing bench characterization system. We also discuss the effectiveness of this bench level characterization approach serving as a platform in the hardware optimization process for Rapid 3200HDD camera board and also to the performances evaluation of multiple linearization approaches.

item.title: Improved Phase Contrast Sensitivity on SP7
item.author: Huang, Chuanyong
item.summary: ​The lateral sensitivity of the SP7 phase contrast system will be approximately 10X better than the SP5 DIC system due to the change in architecture which permits pixels sizes of 0.65 microns compared to spot sizes in SP5 of 16 microns by 92 microns. The height sensitivity to 1.5 micron sized defects will be 1.0 to 1.5 nm. Feasibility studies show that we can put the phase contrast system on the main objective and split off the DIC optics with a dichroic filter just after the main objective. Thus this phase channel will add significant value by capturing phase defects due to stacking faults, slip lines, and residues.​

item.title: Polygon Domain Analysis for Mask Inspection
item.author: Xu, Yin
item.summary: In traditional mask DB inspection, due to the resolution limitation of the optical images of mask inspection system, the geometry classification (one of the key desensing mechanism) of the defects might be unstable and unreliable. In order to break this image resolution bottleneck, we propose a novel algorithm framework called polygon domain analysis (PDA for short), which exports polygons from mask DB as input and then perform polygon healing operation to express the chip patterns of mask DB as complex polygons. Various resolution-independent feature detectors could be developed base on healed DB polygons, bringing benefits of higher accuracy on detections and better controllability on user interactions. This is first attempt in RAPID that explores sophisticated algorithm in the polygon domain. ​

item.title: The Scanning Electron Microscopy and Microanalysis of Optical Materials
item.author: Schultz, William
item.summary:
Since the 1960s, the Scanning Electron Microscope has been an essential lab tool used in the characterization and analysis of metals, minerals and semiconductor materials. Consider the virtues: relatively simple system operation (compared with transmission electron microscopy); quick sample preparation and turn-around time; and the ability to image and analyze features from centimeter through nanometer size scales.

The usual caveat when performing SEM observations: materials should be electro-conductive, or the materials surfaces should be given conductive coatings. How might one perform electron microscopy and microanalysis on non-conductive optical surfaces?

Glasses and dense ceramics can be a real challenge for e-beam tools, unless a conductive surface coating is applied, and the RAPID PhotoPhysics Group has a failure analysis protocol where no coatings are allowed – surfaces are to be observed in the natural state.

With the careful control of system parameters, particularly the beam landing energy, scan rate and surface charge density, optical specimens can become surprisingly stable. This work shows some of the unexpected results of scanning electron microscopy on transparent optical materials as well as metallic reflective optical surfaces used with EUV.​

item.title: A new methodology to control defect detection variability across inspection tools
item.author: Zalicki, Piotr
item.summary:
Defect Detection Variability refers to variations seen in the defect detection results when the same wafer is inspected on several KLA-Tencor inspection tools of the same model. Current matching verification methodologies in manufacturing and in engineering rely on statistical analysis of this variability by comparing defect count on a tested tool to a reference set. The intent of our study is to extend these methodologies to include the intrinsic properties of the defect, a.k.a. defect attributes. The result of this study is a new analysis toolkit released to facilitate the collection and analysis of the defect attributes. We argue that the new information provided by the analysis toolkit can be applied for:

-1- Improving manufacturing pass/fail acceptance criteria,

-2- Feeding tool manufacturing data to engineering for cumulative learning on how to improve inspection stability and matching,

-3- Facilitating the troubleshooting of eld matching issues,

-4- Assessing quantitatively the impact of newly introduced defect attributes on inspection stability and matching early in their development phase.

Results of this study are illustrated with data acquired on the 28XX and 29XX inspection tools.

item.title: Single-Die solution: Cell-to-Cell defect detector
item.author: Luan, Maggie(Hong-Xia)
item.summary: Without database available, reticle inspection can be divided into two categories: die-to-die inspection when there are two or more dies, and single-die inspection when there is only one die on the mask. Compared to die-to-die inspection, single-die inspection is more difficult since there is no other die for reference. This paper proposes a new defect detector named as Cell-to-Cell (C2C) defect detector as single-die solution. C2C can detect defect on the repeating patterns. It can be turned on automatically when repeating patterns are dominant. Currently, C2C is the main detector in the single-die inspection. It can capture the defects of interest (DOI) and keep false count less than customer’s requirement for most plates. ​

item.title: Rapid Prototyping – blueprints for success in time-to-market projects
item.author: Abdallah, Mohammad
item.summary:
Major flash memory makers started research and development in order to migrate flash manufacturing from the traditional (planar) flash to three-dimensional (also known as VNAND). This was dictated by the increasing difficulties of making the planar flash with decreasing design rules. KLA-Tencor initiated the FOCUS program to address the new VNAND technology inspection in the middle of calendar year 2012. From the beginning, the program was intended to be fast time-to-market (TTM) for multiple reasons including getting in the market first and getting as much learning as possible ahead of the competition. A year and a half later, we can say that we succeeded in the goals of getting first to the market and establishing FOCUS tools as the choice (if not the only choice) for customers to inspect their VNAND devices in pursuit of capturing killer buried defects. Testimony to this success is feedback from the three major players where they are using our systems in their process, and the success shows up commercially and in technical feedback.

It is appropriate therefore at this point to reflect back on the work we’ve done in the FOCUS program to get to the market quickly and establish ourselves as the major player in this domain. These lessons learned can be of great value for other projects and programs that will follow suit in the future. We believe that programs such as FOCUS will be more common in the future as KLA-Tencor and other companies adopt newer approaches of customized and customer- or application-specific solutions. Programs responsible for such development must be lean, efficient, and effective in achieving the bottom-line performance metrics established for both the business and the technology. In this paper we are going to share the lessons learned from FOCUS as a TTM project.

​

item.title: DBG2: A Seed-Window based approach
item.author: Xiong, Yan
item.summary: As design rules continue to shrink, systematic defects discovery and monitoring have become increasingly important. DBG used a traditional template matching based approach to identify pattern repeaters. It has issues in accuracy, purity and throughput. DBG2 is a novel seed window based statistical approach. It has demonstrated substantial accuracy/purity and throughput improvement.​

item.title: Leveraging 3D Printing to Accelerate KT Engineering Solutions/Prototyping Process
item.author: Fournier, Steve
item.summary: According to Forbes Magazine (03/27/2012), “3D printing industry will reach $5.2 Billion Worldwide by 2020”, and has evolved from prototyping in various applications to development of actual usable parts and products. 3D printing enables the production of physical items while eliminating the traditional manufacturing channel, and involves building products through layering without the intervention of cutting, drilling, molding, etc. This presentation will discuss the benefits and use cases of 3D printing at KT. Asides from its rapid prototyping capability, 3D printing has the potential to fabricate parts for low volume production such as at KT. ​

item.title: GSS-Engineering Project Execution: From Best Known Practices to an Effective Process
item.author: Fournier, Steve
item.summary: At KLA-Tencor, the Product Life Cycle (PLC) is one of the most important, well established and proven process providing a systematic, predictable and effective guidance for new product development and introduction. This process has been used successfully to bring a new product idea from its infancy, all the way to production and beyond, throughout its support phase (a.k.a. Phase 7). This article will highlight the latest development in defining how we best execute engineering projects in Phase 7, by developing a Project Life Cycle in order to customize the current PLC process for the GSS engineering deliverables. Components of this process may be applicable to sustaining engineering projects in PLC phase 6 where the engineering problems are similar.​

item.title: A Robust and Scalable Scan Engine for Disk/Wafer Inspection
item.author: Jin, Huan

item.title: OH Doped Lamp Glass for WIN Plasma Tools
item.author: Wilson, Lauren
item.summary: This abstract covers experimental results using OH doped glass in the lamps used in Broadband Plasma tools, in order to provide better resistance to Vacuum Ultra-Violet (VUV) radiation. This is especially relevant for Tesla, since many of the VUV induced glass defects create color centers in the Tesla working band (190-260nm).​

item.title: System Level Dynamics for an Inspection Tool
item.author: Subrahmanyan, Pradeep
item.summary: ​​​​​​​As geometries continue to shrink, it has become more and more imperative to have a good system-wide consideration of error budgets. As applied to inspection systems, such an error budget starts with algorithmic considerations – for example, unless absolute positioning accuracy of a defect is important, static accuracy might be completely irrelevant a consideration given the algorithm's handling/realignment of sub-patches in a patch. An approach to modeling the dynamic effects (structural, thermal, acoustic) and determining overall image blur is presented. Such an approach is and can be used to design feedback controllers and generate error motions at the image plane which can then be in turn used to generate blurred images. These blurred images are then used in algo simulations to ensure that sensitivity requirements on the tool are met. ​

item.title: Full Scope of Engineering Handoffs
item.author: Brown, Tony
item.summary: Improve design handoff efficiency by measuring and reducing each phase of activity from planned handoff through ECO release, purchase and production build.​

item.title: Aperture Optimization Methods for Optical Inspection
item.author: Kolchin, Pavel
item.summary:
In this paper we propose and describe the aperture optimization methods and their prototype implementation for the 29XX platform, and we report recent results on gap customer wafers.

​

item.title: Synchrotron-Radiation-Based Short Wavelength Light Sources
item.author: Liu, Yanwei
item.summary: ​​Compact synchrotron radiation sources provide a viable solution for various KT future systems that require high flux, high brightness, and short wavelength (<100 nm) radiation. ​

item.title: Buried DSW wafer
item.author: Abdallah, Mohammad
item.summary:
KLA-Tencor developed and released 3D1 tools for VNAND wafer inspection. Target defects are process defects that are subsurface and can be 2 um or deeper depending on the stack and the architecture. This is the first time in the company and perhaps industry history where the interest is capturing subsurface defects. Up to this point, defects were surface defects or just a few nanometers below the surface. For these surface/shallow defects, the wafer inspection industry has been utilizing visible and UV light, which naturally cannot penetrate deep into the layers. 3D1, on the other hand, targeted subsurface defects by employing near infrared light which can penetrate deeper, and scattered light therefore can be used to detect “buried” defects.

Standard wafers, in general, are used for system calibrations, diags, characterization, and conformance. Currently, we are using standard DSW wafers for calibrations, diags, and conformance but we are missing the characterization component. Standard (surface) DSW wafers cannot provide value in representing and characterizing buried defects. To fill this gap we are launching a project to create a standard wafer with buried programed defects. This wafer will be a standard DSW with VNAND-like stacks on top of it to represent buried defects in a VNAND structure.

​

item.title: Rapid Prototyping - A Step towards being Agile
item.author: Luniya, Suneet
item.summary: An important tenet of agile development is rapid iterations, frequent releases and progressive elaboration of requirements facilitated by direct user involvement in the development process. In this paper we plan to demonstrate the application of these principles of rapid development and early engagement between stakeholders to the development effort when implementing a new feature. We can leverage strengths of Hardware, System and Software Engineers to increase productivity and throughput of development. We contrast the traditional workflow with the workflow in this approach and discuss the role of data in collaboration. We present a case study of developing a new calibration

item.title: Simultaneous Polarization Inspection for Broad Band Plasma Wafer Inspection System
item.author: Nesbitt, Jeremy
item.summary: A modified system architecture for a Broad Band Plasma (BBP) wafer inspection is proposed that uses a Wollaston polarizer for simultaneous H/V polarization. The proposal is in response to increasing multi-pass polarization inspection behavior at 2x nm design rules. The architecture is also extendable for simultaneous inspection of different illumination angles and spectrums for either improved throughput or higher sensitivity through image fusion.​

item.title: Enhancing scatterometry CD signal-to-noise ratio for 1x logic and memory challenges
item.author: Shaughnessy, Derrick

item.title: Auto focus noise reduction with sine modulation/demodulation technology
item.author: Cao, Kai
item.summary:
​Auto focus system is a key sub-system in wafer inspection tools. It tracks the height of the wafer surface and maintains optics in focus to get sharp images. Reducing auto focus noise can improve image sharpness, quality and then increase the defect capture rate and reduce false defects.

WIN's current auto focus system is able to meet most of the system requirements. However, in some light starve area the signal to noise ratios (SNR) from auto focus sensors are too low, which downgrades auto focus performance. This paper introduces a new method to reduce auto focus noise. The method generated a sine wave modulated AF illuminate light and applies digital demodulation technology to processes focus signals. It greatly reduced the noise of auto focus signals and improved the SNR. This new method has been implemented in a newly designed PCB. The test results show that the AF sensor noise has been reduced over 5 times and the auto focus signal noise in light starve area been reduced over 7 times. Using this new method has expanded the low reflection working area and allowed the tools to inspect the area where previous auto focus systems cannot do.

item.title: Framework for Inspector-SEM Connectivity with Responsive Sampling
item.author: Lennek, Michael
item.summary: We are currently developing a platform-independent framework that allows for a user to choose an automated method of selecting an initial batch of defects. This initial selection could leverage a combination of design information, optical inspection information, and patch images information. We then connect to a KT SEM tool and immediately grab the SEM images corresponding to the initially selected defects. These SEM images are then analyzed to determine how the selection criteria should respond in order to choose a “better” subsequent batch of defects. This process can be repeated for a selected number of iterations and the user can, at runtime, modify the metric for successful defect selections. The user could even provide interactive feedback to modify the selection strategy based on what the user has already observed. This framework is currently being tested for SEM review sampling but could easily be extended into other problem domains, such as determining a best optical mode. This framework is designed to be easily extensible, allowing the user to leverage many analysis tools already present on our inspectors and can, in principle, be integrated into many new or existing KLA-Tencor platforms. ​

item.title: High Speed Logarithm Analog Design
item.author: Lim, Jeongsik
item.summary: The classic diode and OP-AMP based logarithmic amplifier suffers from limited frequency response, especially at low input levels.In this paper, we present a High Speed Logarithm Amplifier operating from DC to 250MHz. By adopting the current buffer topology, the dynamic resistance of diode is isolated from the circuit bandwidth and this approach offers a more flexible methodology to achieve high performance over increased bandwidths.​

item.title: Stage Amplifier Design by Using Safe Operational Area (SOA) of Transistors on the Amplifier
item.author: Cao, Wei
item.summary:
​The stage amplifier is a critical part on the stage motion control loop. Most of the electrical hardware problem comes out from it, because it is the only part in analog and high power in the servo loop.

A simulation model was created based on the motor specification, stage parameters, POR, 7 segment motion and amplifier specification, and was implemented in excel sheet. By this model, the power on each transistor of the amplifier can be plotted together with the safe operational area (SOA) of the transistor and give out a very clear requirement of amplifier for a certain POR. This model can be also used to simulate the impact on the force ripple for the amplifier offset, gain difference, motor coil imbalance. The model was verified by the real tested data. This model was used in the design of the amplifiers for VQ, 96xx, 98xx and 450 stages.

item.title: Reduce wafer vibration using squeezing air damping
item.author: Wang, Chunhai
item.summary: Squeezing Air Damping is quantitatively analyzed for wafer application. The technology is adopted in WaferSight 3 as a key architecture change to control the vibration. Air damping is proved to be very effective, without which t he measurement is almost impossible. ​

item.title: 'Topaz' Inspector for SiC
item.author: Ramachandran, Mahendra
item.summary: A key technical challenge for the inspection of SiC substrate and SiC epi is that they are typically only 350 m m thick and transparent to visible light. Consequently, backside scattered light separation techniques based on spatial filters used in the Candela 8620 for sapphire inspection are insufficient. This paper presents our “Topaz” design, which solves this issue by leveraging SiC absorption at 355nm. It allows excellent sensitivity to micro-scratches and micro-pits, and enables photoluminescence (PL) contrast on otherwise invisible epi layer defects. Experimental results and a possible extension to classification in multiple spectral bins are also presented. ​

item.title: Mastering the Statistics of Inspection Matching
item.author: Biagini, Karen
item.summary: Characterization of matching behavior for Broadband Plasma is allowing us to make better decisions on new specs, respond faster in troubleshooting using a new sequential testing method, and check matching robustness on new products.

item.title: Service Action Level System FMECA for Improved Tool Serviceability
item.author: Lee, Chris W.
item.summary: Gaps in diagnostics, error messages, and troubleshooting procedures increase downtime and cost of service for key system-level failure modes. However, at KT system-level FMECA’s typically have not been developed due to the complexity of the task. Primarily subsystem FMECA’s are developed. Using a system-level FMECA in Phase 3a makes it possible to develop a higher uptime, lower cost-of-service product. This talk discusses a method to reduce the complexity of developing a system-level FMECA while capturing the most likely failure modes and high-level symptoms as they will be seen and addressed by service engineers. ​

item.title: A dark field pupil mapping tool for aperture discovery
item.author: Boatwright, Thomas
item.summary: We show that custom apertures that select illumination directions in a 29XX pupil can be used to determine a variety of dark field apertures. This technique has the advantage of being sensitive to cases in which a defect produces an asymmetric response to illumination. Future work will involve validating the dark field pupil mapper by constructing the apertures suggested from the pupil maps. In the presentation, we will discuss results from tests with these newly developed apertures.

item.title: Reducing the Cost of Match Monitoring through Tool Diagnostics
item.author: Lee, Chris W.
item.summary: System monitoring is critical both in during the spec validation portion of the design process, and for the customer using a KT tool in the field. Customers often spend a significant portion of valuable tool time to monitor system matching using product wafers. Because monitoring data is so costly to collect, data density is lower than desirable, and customers are at risk of missing some excursions for hours or days before an inspection tool issue is caught. This talk describes the strategy WIN uses to achieve out-of-the-box tool matching using methods other than customer wafers. This approach improves KT and customer confidence in tool stability by increasing the frequency and relevance of data collection while reducing the cost of monitoring vs. the traditional wafer based approach.​

item.title: Helical Beams for Optical Wafer Inspection
item.author: Haurylau, Mikhail
item.summary: ​A new imaging method has been proposed for defect inspection of 3-D structures, which has a potential for z-discrimination of defects and noise sources. A working prototype has been fabricated and tested using BBP inspection tools. The proof of principle has been achieved by demonstrating that surface particles and previous layer nuisance defects can be separated by > 3 sigma difference in measured PSF angle. To make this method applicable to gap layers, the error of the measurement has to be reduced by improvements in AF system and image deconvolution, both of which will be discussed.

item.title: Impact of DUV Exposure on ArF and EUV Resists in Overlay and CD Metrology
item.author: Treyger, Leon
item.summary:
Ever continuing decrease in critical dimension (CD) and improvements in resolution of optical lithography dictated switch to shorter wavelengths, first to DUV (248nm, 193nm) and now to EUV (13.5nm). Correspondingly, photoresists have to be very sensitive to these wavelengths by design. This, in turn, poses tremendous challenges for optical metrology (OM) and process control where photoresist layer pattern has to be used for measurements, e.g. in overlay and litho CD measurements.
It becomes very important to investigate not only resist / BARC damage thresholds in DUV-UV part of spectrum, but also DUV light - resist interaction and damage mechanisms. One of the potential solutions combines use of selected discrete DUV wavelengths that has lower impact on resist properties, and limitation of dose to levels below damage threshold. This work addresses initial results of such investigation including resist damage levels on specific wavelengths, and comparison of impact of broadband DUV-UV illumination with that of discrete wavelengths.

​

item.title: State of KT Art in Design for Service
item.author: Benitez, Eva
item.summary:
Design for Service is becoming increasingly complex as customer's uptime and cost of service requirements continue to rise. Examples from SP7 and other recent KT programs are used to demonstrate how KT designs are responding to these tightened requirements. Design for parts cost, service access, IP protection, and monitoring examples are included.

​

item.title: Float like a Cloud, Sting like a Bee: Maximizing the IMC's Potential
item.author: Thaker, Darshan
item.summary:
The Image Computer (IMC) in current generation WIN tools is a collection of servers grouped into rows and columns. How can we change this design into a true cluster, where all nodes are equal? What benefits would it give us? How can we design the IMC software to allow the cluster to behave as a private-cloud for the tool? How could more than one WIN tool share the same IMC Cloud? Could it grow into a KT-Cloud, shared by all KT tools in a fab?

The theme of the KT Engineering Conference is "Accelerate Innovation"; towards this end, this abstract lays down a marker for the development of the IMC. While there are no easy answers to the questions in the first paragraph, as a first step, this abstract begins with the motivation for going down this road, and then shines a light some of the benefits and on the associated technical risks.

item.title: Of Needles and Haystacks: Employing Big Data Techniques to Analyze IMC Usage Patterns
item.author: Thaker, Darshan
item.summary: ​Finding the balance between compute power, memory and I/O is the key challenge in making the most efficient use of Image Computer (IMC) resources at our disposal. While different KT divisions place different requirements on their IMC, thereby creating their own definition of the "right balance"; the basic components of the balance do not change. In the WIN division, we have recently introduced always-on mechanisms to gather detailed metrics on resource usage within the IMC. This abstract gives a brief overview of how this data is gathered followed by what data we capture and how we analyze it. The goal is to find answers to architecture-level questions. The questions we are interested in can be classified into these broad categories: Comparison against predicted models (What is the gap between the actual usage and the predicted model? Why?), degradation analysis (When performance is poor, what resource is dragging it down? What is the trend?), planning (If the requirement becomes 4X of the current requirement, how will we find the right balance?), finding co-relations (For system-level variables like number of defects, how does this balance tilt or shift?)

item.title: SCALPEL: Software-tools as Catalysts in Addressing Problems and Escalations
item.author: Thaker, Darshan
item.summary: ​In WIN, our defect-detection tools generate copious amounts of data on a daily-basis and based on our requirements, we have mechanisms to analyze this data. However, when confronted with unusual or not-seen-before problems, our current methods often fall short. Solving such problems is generally dependent on obtaining a singular insight that makes the entire picture fall into place. The driving idea behind this paper is that lightweight and well-defined software tools, when used judiciously, can act as catalysts in unearthing such insights. This abstract introduces SCALPEL, a set of lightweight software tools that were created with the idea of gaining insights from data. Links to a live visualization demo showcasing SCALPEL are provided. This is followed by a brief discussion of how SCALPEL was used to determine the cause of a difficult throughput bug in Elise and Elise-SENS tools. SCALPEL is not one single piece of software, but a combination of small, lightweight tools that are generic, but work well with each-other and can therefore be used to address a wide variety of problems.

item.title: Patterned Wafer Image Compression
item.author: Murugan, Ramesh
item.summary:
Compression of wafer images is especially important when getting high resolution debug image data from the field, archiving data for replay at a later time in software simulators such as virtual inspector.

This paper compares the time, compression ratio and capabilities like ROI decoding, progressive display of classical methods for lossy and lossless image compression. It then discusses about the models to further compress the data using using knowledge of repeating die/field structures found in patterned wafers. The classical methods explored in this paper are JPEG, JPEG2000, Principal Component Analysis, PNG and Zip.

The paper then compares various approaches to exploit domain-specific knowledge to improve upon the results. A simple prediction using the die and field knowledge has reduced the entropy of a field image by 2-3 (8 is the highest). Furthermore, we believe that this approach will eventually lead to a novel method for defect detection using the predictive models used for compression. ​

item.title: Battling 'Gradient Thermal Lensing' Induced by High Laser Power
item.author: Liu, Fei
item.summary: ​This paper described a real case study of "gradient thermal lensing" induced by high power laser on the newly developed Surfscan@SP5 product. This issue has been on the critical path for Phase 3 exit and had been the hottest "gating item" for SP5 product shipment. The theory is explored and a model that has shown excellent correlation to the tool data is developed. They played critical roles in solving the issue successfully.

item.title: Novel Data-Driven Approach to DOI Separation
item.author: Plihal, Martin
item.summary: In this paper, we propose a new method for analyzing inspection data to assist users in separating DOIs from nuisance. We envision this type of analysis to be useful in DOI discovery process, and during creation of nuisance filters and classifiers.​

item.title: DUV Objective Lens based on “Imaging Radiometer” Image Quality Metric
item.author: Whiteside, Bret
item.summary: ​This paper described a real case study of DUV objective designs based on “Imaging Radiometer” application for use in Surfscan SP7 product. This objective has been the highest risk component needed to produce this imaging system since it was first envisioned as a major paradigm shift for Surfscan’s traditional non-imaging collector designs. The concepts to develop a low-cost alternative to a diffraction-limited imaging objective are discussed. As applied these concepts have successfully reduced the cost of this objective to $120k in production

item.title: Accelerating ADC algorithm computation with GPU computing
item.author: Suh, Jung
item.summary:
Automatic Defect Classification (ADC) automatically assigns the defect class type into each defect, so it has many benefits over the manual classification by human inspector in consistency and fast performance. The ADC software is supposed to be installed within eDR 7110 tool. For the automatic classification of each defect type, ADC algorithm computes a measurable, quantifiable, mathematical "attribute" of the defect such as intensity, shape, texture, background and topography. Since ADC should deal with huge number of defects, we need fast and reliable processing. Currently, KLA-Tencor ADC is mainly composed of MATLAB codes with some C modules via C-MEX. Since MATLAB has the vector/matrix representation of its data, which is suitable for parallel processing, it can benefit a lot from Graphic Processing Unit (GPU) acceleration. NVidia's Compute Unified Device Architecture (CUDA) is a parallel computing architecture originally designed for computer game, but it is getting reputations in general science and technology fields for its efficient massive computation power. Recently almost all laptops and desktop computers have NVidia's graphic card as a default hardware installation option, we can take advantage of the parallel processing power of GPU and abundant CUDA scientific libraries for accelerating our engineering MATLAB codes without extra cost.

From the CUDA conversion of the single function revealed to be the busiest function during the profiling, we improve the speed about 41.8% enhancement than the pure m codes for ADC computation. The first thing to do for speed optimization is profiling, from which we can identify the target modules to be converted to CUDA functions. Second, when we plan to convert from MATLAB m codes to GPU-enabled c-mex codes, we should consider the size of the data and the frequency of data transfer between the CPU memory and GPU device memory based on different codes.

​

item.title: Surface Characterization of EUV optical surfaces using PSD
item.author: Soto, Eduardo
item.summary: ​​Using Power Spectral Density (PSD) to characterize EUV optical performance.

item.title: Multiple Lamphouse Configuration to Increase Light Output for the WIN Brightfield Plasma Source
item.author: Yadav, Rahul
item.summary: A novel idea of combining light beams coming out of multiple lamphouses into a single beam is proposed in this abstract ​

item.title: DNA Biomaterial Based Solution Processible Sensitive Deep Ultraviolet Bio-photodetector
item.author: Zhou, Bin
item.summary: Solution processible DNA-based bio-photodetectors (BPD) ha s evolved as a promising cost effective, facile fabrication alternative to traditional expital growth material based photodetectors. Some of the significant advantages of these so-called bio-photodetectors include cost effective biodegradable polymeric material DNA, which is typically a waste material of fishing industrial , facile processing, versatility of charge mobility of chemical structure from advances in DNA biochemistry and polymer chemistry. Due to its nature of large band gap (4.7 eV) ， DNA is a promising candidate for deep UV photodetector. However, poor stability and inefficient photo-generated electron-hole separation and extraction limits its further development. The responsivity of such DNA-based DUV PDs obtained a major boost with the introduction of the electron acceptor layer phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester(PCBM) and achieved 0.73 A/W @ 1V bias voltage under DUV lamp illumination. The highly conductive DNA biomaterial, combined with nanocrystalline PCBM and hole trap functionalization, underlie the superior performance achieved in this readily fabricated DUV BPDs. The BPD devices fabricated in this study are made by a solution-based process and large device area roll-by-roll inkprint can be achieved by this process at relatively low cost ​

item.title: Optimized Laser Parameters for Improved Collectible Output Power from a Laser Sustained Plasma Source
item.author: Wittenberg, Joshua
item.summary: We have determined the optimal combination of laser fiber diameter and wavelength for achieving the maximum collectible power from the next-generation Broadband Laser Sustained Plasma (LSP) Lamp Houses. We have observed that the combination of 2000 m m fiber size with the 1044 + 1069 nm wavelength pair provides us the best performance for all the 292x wavelength bands and pixel sizes. This configuration allows us to continue scaling with the collectible power roadmap for the next generation tools, with less increase in the pump laser power, and while reducing the RPC of the current diode-based laser design, without necessitating the switch to a 1.5-2x higher-RPC active-fiber laser system. ​

item.title: Algorithm based repeated pattern recognition framework
item.author: Murugan, Mike
item.summary: A Pattern is imaged under different optics e.g. magnification, illumination incidence, collection apertures, polarizations will vary in size and frequency consistently. Pattern may be rotated and part of the pattern may be out of focus when imaged. A generic solution may not be reliable for handling above mentioned use cases. Hence a new algorithm based pattern recognition framework was developed. This framework predicts regions of interest based on frequency of geometry and uses a collection of algorithms to detect individual geometry that comprise the pattern, discards dirt, discards blemishes and it uses criteria to stop the processing after sufficient information is extracted from the image. The architecture, advantages and limitations of this framework are discussed in this paper.

item.title: Electrical Contact Fires - Design for Manufacturability, Reliability and Safety
item.author: El-kareh, Edwin
item.summary: A significant number of electrical fires at KT are located at electrical contact points. The root cause of these fires is the lack of a gas-tight seal at the connection points in the power circuit which lead to thermal runaway. Understanding of the purpose of a gas-tight seal and how to achieve it will prevent future electrical fires in KLA-Tencor tools at our customer sites. ​

item.title: PDA Image Rendering with Flexible Apertures
item.author: Huber, Markus
item.summary: ​Currently, the PDA image rendering does not consider the inspection mode and the corresponding optics parameters, like spectral bands or apertures or dark field modes. This can limit the application of CBI or increase the recipe setup time. We propose an approach that incorporates the illumination and collection aperture into the image rendering in order to improve the alignment during the inspection.

item.title: Structured illumination microscopy in a wafer inspection system
item.author: Shankar, Premchandra
item.summary: Structured illumination has been widely used to increase the optical resolution beyond the diffraction limit of the systems such as microscopy in biomedical applications. In this paper we discuss structured illumination approach to demonstrate the spatial resolution improvement in a broadband incoherent inspection tool. We present results from the simulations of such a system followed by the experimental validations.​

item.title: Low Jitter PLL System Design and Characterization
item.author: Zhao, Jingjun
item.summary: Jitter is the undesired deviation from true periodicity of an assumed periodic signal in electronics and telecommunications, often in relation to a reference clock source. It is a key performance factor in a high-speed data communication and high accuracy clock distribution system. In such a system design, among all the possible parametric issues, jitter has risen to the top as one of the most significant and is therefore having a huge impact on the design, operation, and proof of many of today’s products. Design and characterization of low jitter PLL system become a very important topic in modern technology advance. This paper, based on our Denali electronics design, will cover three aspects of the low jitter PLL system. 1) Jitter source; 2) Low jitter PLL system design; 3) Jitter characterization. ​

item.title: Spec Auto Corrector in TDI Sensor Calibration
item.author: Gao, George (Wenzhi)
item.summary: an automated spec (specification) correction method is proposed in Broad Band TDI Sensor calibration. Wherein the method a spec correction rule based algorithm is adopted to detect and correct the wrong spec when the TDI sensor calibration is running. With little or no human intervention this corrector can adjust the too loose or too tight spec and find the optimistic spec and save it into the database (MDS). The approach helps to efficiently generate the final spec for a Wafer Inspection Alpha and beta tool. ​

item.title: Software Solutions for Aperture Flexibility
item.author: Atluri, Krishna
item.summary:
Sensitivity is the key component for WIN broadband tools where the ability to detect defects defines the bottom line. This has driven rapidly changing illumination and imaging aperture definitions that WIN software had difficulty supporting. Elise has introduced a new flexible illumination technology that allows users to define apertures on the fly. In this paper, we will cover how the software architecture that was developed over a decade has facilitated creating new aperture definitions without the need for significant software changes. This flexibility has enabled new business opportunities like customizable apertures and new applications like AccuRay.

​

item.title: Self Calibration: Exposing asymmetry in symmetrical structures
item.author: Hale, Layton
item.summary: ​Several fundamental and distinct metrology techniques, collectively known as self calibration, enable absolute accuracies approaching limits set by the sensor resolution and the stability of the system. The techniques to be presented include reversal, closure, multi-step averaging, and multi-probe method. The common element among them is the use of redundant measurements to expose asymmetry in supposedly symmetrical structures. This information may be used to physically correct form errors or to compensate position errors typically through software. The intent of this paper is to instill the readers with a basic understanding and appreciating for self calibration so they may take advantage of these simple and powerful ideas to push the limits of accuracy.

item.title: Milestone-Based System Integration Planning and Tracking
item.author: Gu, Ping
item.summary: A practical milestone-based planning and tracking method for integrating multi-discipline and complex system features has been developed by applying basic system engineering principles to create and an integration plan. ​

item.title: Concurrent and Component-Based Image Computer Development
item.author: Mathew, Ashok
item.summary: ​A concurrent and component based Image Computer hardware and software development approach has been matured through the development of the many generations of image computers in the WIN division. This paper dwells on the details of such a development method that has been so successful.

item.title: A Systematic Approach to Minimizing Errors in Optical Radiation Measurement
item.author: Guan, Yu
item.summary: Measurement of optical radiation has broad applications both within KLA-Tencor and in semiconductor industries overall, including IC, solid state lighting and solar cells. It is involved in testing of most light sources, e.g. lamps, lasers, and LED’s, which are components on inspection and metrology tools, or the products tested by these tools. Errors in the measurement of such devices often directly impact the performance of the tools, as well as yield, price, and cost of the products. Accurate and reliable measurement is therefore critical for us and our customers. We have investigated the significant but often overlooked errors in such measurements, and addressed them individually with methods for correcting or reducing them. These are summarized into a systematic approach for obtaining accurate measurements. The result was quantitatively validated with NIST’s certified measurement. This investigation was carried out with tungsten lamps and LED’s. But the approach is applicable to all light sources. The validation result demonstrates that for luminous flux this approach allows us to reduce measurement error to near the limit which is NIST’s uncertainty of ~ 1%. The application of correction algorithms enables the use of relatively small spectrometers and integrating spheres to accomplish this performance at low cost. ​

item.title: VNAND Process Monitoring Using NIR Inspection Tool
item.author: Baris, Oksen
item.summary: This paper describes the challenges associated with 3D memory devices inspection and also the innovative technologies and methodologies developed by KLA-Tencor to face these challenges. The core of the data provided is based from early engagements with Toshiba, Hynix and Samsung through demo, beta and evaluation work.​

item.title: The Development of the Flexible Aperture Mechanism for Broadband Wafer Inspection System
item.author: Zheng, Yu
item.summary: ​​​​​​​​​​In the abstract described the motivation, concept, implementation, calibration and extension for the flexibale aperture mechanism for the broadband wafer inspection system. ​

item.title: SpectraWafer - an optical sensor wafer to measure plasma non-uniformity
item.author: OBrien, Kevin
item.summary: ​​Plasma etching plays a key role in semiconductor processing. As feature sizes of integrated circuits shrink, control of the critical parameters in the plasma etch process becomes more and more important. Modern plasma etch processes use a combination of ion bombardment and chemically reactive neutral species to achieve anisotropic etching with good selectivity . In this paper we present a sensor wafer to monitor the density of reactive neutral species at different locations above the wafer surface. In a plasma, or "glow discharge", neutrals are excited through collisions with energetic electrons and upon relaxation, they can emit photons of a characteristic wavelength. Here, we describe a sensor design concept to monitor these characteristic emissions. Initial prototype testing results from 300mm commercial etch chambers are presented, showing sensitivity to changes in chemical uniformity of the plasma.​

item.title: Sensor Wafer for In-situ Measurement in Plasma Etch
item.author: Sun, Mei
item.summary:
Semiconductor plasma etching processes are sensitive to several parameters of the process recipe. Typical variables available to the engineer are RF power and bias, gas type, flow rate, flow distribution, chuck temperature, and time. All of these parameters are tuned to achieve the desired etching reaction on the wafer surface. The result of an imperfect recipe, a malfunctioning chamber, or misunderstood impact of a recipe variable can lead to yield loss, in the way of spatial non-uniform etch rate, and a variety of other pattern defects. As the industry pursues structural and material alternatives (ie. VNAND and FinFET), etch control is becoming more critical. As the feature size shrinks below 40nm, more control demand has been placed on plasma etch processes, especially for high aspect ratio. Pulsing plasma has been broadly used to improve selectivity, reduce hard mask loss and reduce micro-loading.

While process parameters are available at the tool level for recipe tuning, the tool level adjustment does not always produce the expected results on the wafer surface. The wafer level sensors that measures the wafer surface conditions have demonstrated unique values in correlating the process conditions to the uniformity of the processed wafer.​

item.title: Integrated All Lens Array Design of Flood Illumination for Optical Inspection
item.author: Chen, Peter
item.summary: Dual Lens array with one generating hexgon far field pattern(pupil lens array(PLA)) and one generating rectangular far field pattern(field lens array(FLA)) are deployed to an illuminator relay at field conjugate(PLA) and pupil conjugate(FLA) to generating tophat illumination pupil and field for optical inspection.​

item.title: A Network Oblivious Software Architecture
item.author: Roulo, Mark
item.summary:
Introduction
For the past 10 years, the Cougar software used by WIN has shipped with a network
oblivious software architecture. Any of the roughly 100 software components of the
architecture can be located on any of the computers in the cluster that ships with the
tool. This paper discusses how this was achieved.​

item.title: Direct Measurements of Porosity of Thin Films Using a Gaseous Adsorption and Spectroscopic Ellipsometry (GASE)
item.author: Krishnan, Shankar
item.summary: ​A new method to measure the porosity of thin films using gaseous adsorption and desorption combined with in situ spectroscopic ellipsometry is described. In this method, the change in refractive index of a porous film is measured under conditions where the composition and humidity of the gas filling the pores is varied. The technique represents a substantial improvement over conventional approaches that require vacuum systems and fluid filling of the pores. Preliminary results using this new technique on porous TEOS films show good accuracy to reference metrology. Extension of this approach using gases of different molecular sizes and controlled saturation is described. ​

item.title: Interoperability – The promise and peril
item.author: Reddy, Dev
